speakerposition: Minister of Veterans Affairs
speechtext: that Bill C-70, an act to amend the Criminal Code (jury), be read the third time and passed.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, Bill C-70, an act to amend the Criminal Code, is a series of amendments that deal specifically with jury selection in Canada. It is a direct response to a decision of the Supreme Court of Canada in the case of Regina v Bain. That decision was handed down on January 23, 1992. It struck down certain provisions in the Criminal Code as they relate to jury selection. Specifically, the Supreme Court of Canada felt that the present jury selection method as contained in the Criminal Code placed the Crown at an unfair advantage vis-a-vis defence counsel.
This bill that is before Parliament is a direct response to that. Prior to its tabling on I believe April 6 of this year, there were consultations with the Canadian Bar Association and other interested individuals as to what should go into this particular bill.
I believe that because of the consultation process that took place, this bill is as non-controversial as it is. There is a recognition within the legal community that these
changes can, should and must be made. Indeed, they must be in place by July 23, 1992, because the Supreme Court of Canada suspended the operation of its decision for a period of six months. Therefore, we are under some time constraints to have this bill enacted.
When this bill went before the legislative committee, there were no witnesses before the committee. No one expressed a desire to appear. The bill passed the legislative committee without amendment and was returned to the House of Commons for the report stage.
There was an amendment by the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam that was dealt with yesterday. It concerned the multicultural justice review. I indicated to the hon. member that study would continue and that it would continue within the Department of Justice. As well, I indicated that if the hon. member wished to pursue an outside inquiry, certainly that was something that was within the purview of he and his fellow colleagues who sit on the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General. They could do that.
There is some urgency to the particular bill that is before Parliament. It addresses a specific problem. It goes further than was required by the Supreme Court of Canada inasmuch as the procedure in Bill C-70 allows the selection of jurors to be done on an alternate basis between the defence counsel and the Crown attorney. That in and of itself was not called for by the Regina v Bain decision, but we went slightly beyond that in the interest of fairness in the judicial process. That is welcomed.
At one point, my friend in the New Democratic Party suggested that we might consider abolishing the ability of the Crown attorney to reject certain jurors. That would be going too far. Most people would recognize that the Crown is there to represent the interests of the people of this country and however else we might design the judicial system and the jury selection, there should be an even handed approach between the defence and the Crown.

Government Orders
Bill C-70 accomplishes that. As well, I might point out that the specific provisions that related to the territories allowed juries of six people. Those references have now been removed from the Criminal Code. That as well is a step in the right direction.
The bill was passed by the legislative committee and sent back here. The government certainly has not dawdled in bringing this matter forward.
I ask hon. members in the best interests of the judicial system, the legal system of Canada, to pass this bill as quickly as possible because this is a non-controversial bill. It is good. It is required. Every major group in Canada that has had an opportunity to either be consulted or to comment welcomed this bill. I ask the House of Commons to pass this bill as quickly as possible and send it on to the other place.

Madam Speaker, I thank my hon. colleague for his comments. We participated, of course, in the legislative committee and I have checked with my colleagues on the subject.
Bill C-70, as the hon. member said, is a bill that essentially relates to a better system for the selection of jurors. We agree it is critical to the legal system. While it may not be non-controversial, which I can certainly agree with, it is time sensitive. We are pleased to see it here at this particular point in time.
It is in response to the charter and it is time sensitive. We have no amendments. We have no problems with the bill. We would also like to see it go forward as quickly as possible.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to speak to this bill at third reading stage on behalf of the New Democratic Party.
I should tell the House that back in 1980, the Law Reform Commission recommended changes. Governments, both this Conservative government and the previous Liberal government, never did anything about it. In fact, we see once again a government that is reacting to a decision of the Supreme Court. This is the pattern for this government.
The Minister of Justice would have us believe that she is taking a lot of initiatives. In fact, her initiatives,
including the new rape shield bill which we support, are still reactions to decisions that were rendered by the Supreme Court of Canada. In other words, the government has to do something. One should see that pattern, and this is another example of the pattern.
The parliamentary secretary admitted that there is a report on multicultural issues, racism and racism in the justice system. This is a priority issue in Canada today. Just look at the Lewis report of the other day in Toronto. Look at other patterns across this country, some of which I will speak about in a minute. There was a report. It had to be dug out of this government. It was an uncompleted report by the Law Reform Commission. The government has abolished the commission now. This report was dug out by a reporter from the Toronto Star and we never had the benefit of considering this report before our legislative committee.
I got a lot of flack yesterday from the Conservative opposition, including some cabinet ministers-Conservative government, it will soon be opposition-when I raised the issue and delayed the passing of this bill.
I had a simple request which was that the report be completed. It is a crucial report. We just had a draft report. I asked that the report be completed and that it be done by an outside person. In other words, it should be done by a consultant, that it be continued by people who were doing work for the Law Reform Commission. I wanted that procedure so that it could be tabled in the House of Commons and made public. It would be an objective report.
We have been offered a report which will be done by the Department of Justice. It may never see the light of day. We do not have to get these reports. They are not tabled as a right.
What can I do? I could go and pursue the issue in the justice committee. That is not good enough.
The government wants our co-operation. We have given it a lot of co-operation on a number of bills. Surely my request could have been met. The parliamentary secretary could have said: "This is an important issue. The Conservative government is concerned about racism. We are concerned about these problems, we are going to complete this report and we are going to table it in the House of Commons."
June 12, 1992

This is a rigid ultra-conservative government on this issue. It does not have much interest, as shown by its actions in multiculturalism or in attacking these racist problems in our society. That is the only conclusion I can draw from that rigidity of the parliamentary secretary in this matter. He is not always that rigid, I will give him that. I do not know why he was so rigid in this case, but he was. I think the country is poorer for it.
We had a great opportunity here when we were forced to take a look at the jury selection process in the draft amendments. It is unfortunate we did not take time to examine the issues more thoroughly and we did not use the opportunity to address some of the features of the justice system which have recently come into question. I found our justice system unequal.
I will state the problem, to make it simple. We are dealing in this bill with the question of how a defence counsel or Crown counsel-and I have been both-in all levels of all courts in Canada can choose a jury. People are selected by lot, they come before the court and a jury is chosen.
In our system, defence counsel or Crown counsel can stand up and challenge someone, not have that person on the jury because they do not like the colour of their skins or they might think they are Jewish, Arab, aboriginal, or of some other group. We have a case directly on that point which I will mention in a moment.
We should not have a system like that. It is a challenge on a purely subjective criteria and we should at least have a look at that. That is what I am saying. It is why I was pressing for the report to be completed. I hope the government will listen.
I am on a little bit of a tangent here but the parliamentary secretary said I had suggested in committee that the Crown counsel not even have a challenge. Let me suggest to you what the argument is.
Remember the government makes the laws through the majority in Parliament. The government sets up the courts. The government chooses and pays the judges. The government pays the police. The government has such control of the system that it is not really equal.
One way of giving the accused a better break in this matter is to consider the fact that it should be only the accused person who has the challenge and not the Crown. The Crown has to take the ordinary people from
Government Orders
the street. I put that out. Of course, we are not going to do that and it will not come for some time.
Canadians can be rightly proud of the commitment we have made as a people to the principles of equality and fairness and we have all done that. Sections 15 and 28 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms guarantee all Canadians the right to equality.
It is because of that statement of principles we have rulings like the Bain case we are dealing with from the Supreme Court of Canada and has forced the government to make these amendments to the jury selection process. Both Liberal and Conservative governments were not going to act on their own. It took the court to force them to act. It took the Charter of Rights and Freedoms to get the court that power.
There is more to the standards we have set for ourselves when it comes to fairness or equal rights. Section 27 of the charter provides: "This Charter shall be interpreted in a manner consistent with the preservation and enhancement of the multicultural heritage of Canadians".
We as a people have recognized the multicultural and multiracial composition of our society and have stated clearly our commitment to respecting the diversity in the Canadian Multiculturalism Act.
We have stated clearly that all of us deserve equal treatment and equal protection regardless of race. We are not asking that anybody get unequal treatment. We want equal treatment for everyone. It seems to me it is a fundamental principle of democracy; it is certainly a fundamental principle of what my party stands for.
Canada has signed the International Convention on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination. Clearly, Canadians believe that racism is not to be tolerated in our society, yet we also have a good indication that Canadians believe that racism or racist attitudes are increasing in Canada.
I mentioned the Lewis report. A recent Angus Reid poll for Southam News found that 55 per cent of Canadians feel that racism is increasing in Canada. What is perhaps even more disconcerting, there is growing evidence to show our justice system has elements of racism and that is a serious charge.
Unfortunately, there are some individuals working within the justice system who do not hold to the principles I have outlined. The inquiry into the killing of Leo Chance in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan revealed there are Aryan nation sympathizers in the police de-

Government Orders
partment in that city. Other inquiries have found individuals who promote and act on racial stereotyping in cities like Montreal. These things need to be said.
These incidents and individuals must be dealt with. Even more urgent is the need to deal with the systemic flaws which make our system racist or at the very least undermine the perception of fairness and equality. For example, visible minorities make up over 20 per cent of the population of Toronto, but only 6.2 per cent of its uniformed police. That can and should be changed.
There have been numerous studies revealing just how deeply flawed our justice system is when it comes to fairness and equality for visible minorities and even how deeply flawed and prone to racism the jury selection process can be. The jury selection process is what we are debating now.
A draft paper from the Law Reform Commission, the paper I was talking about that was only recently brought to our attention, notes that between 1974 and 1989 nine commissions investigated allegations involving racism and ethnic discrimination in the justice system and made over 229 recommendations for changes.
We will remember the Marshall inquiry, for example. We had eight other commissions and they made 229 recommendations for changes. The draft paper I spoke about states: "The repetitiveness of the proposals reveals almost two decades of", to be charitable, "slowness in reaction, a phenomenon that has been characterized as the gap between discourse and political will". That is an academic putting it. I will be less polite: we have been dragging our feet.
The inquiry into the Donald Marshall case and the Manitoba inquiry into the deaths of Helen Betty Osborne and John Joseph Harper are two of the inquiries which most of us are familiar with.
The Marshall inquiry found that throughout the entire history of the province of Nova Scotia no aboriginal person had been on a jury. This is the fair jury system we are rushing through the House today.
While the inquiry found no evidence to suggest aboriginal people were deliberately excluded from jury duty, it did strongly recommend, as did counsel for the Attorney
General, a full study concerning proportional representation of visible minorities on juries. We never even considered that in this bill when we opened up the Criminal Code-and we do not do it very often-to look at the provisions on the jury. That is a shame for this House.
In Manitoba the inquiry found that on the Osborne case there was clear evidence that six aboriginal people who were called to the jury panel were excluded because of their race. All were challenged by Johnston's lawyer, Greg Brodsky. Mr. Brodsky excluded all of them through use of his peremptory challenges. The result was there were no aboriginal people on the jury that heard a case involving the brutal murder of an aboriginal woman in an area in which a large percentage of the population is aboriginal.
Was that jury really representative of the community? Was that justice the way we want to see it?
As a result of the finding of the aboriginal justice inquiry of Manitoba, it was recommended that the Criminal Code be amended so that only the challenge to prospective jurors be challenges for cause, that stand asides and peremptory challenges be eliminated.
Bill C-70 only removes stand asides and only addresses the perception of unfair advantage of the Crown. It does not address the use of peremptory challenges on the basis of race or culture. It is purely subjective. We could have another case like the Osborne case where defence counsel or even Crown counsel could make sure that the jury did not represent any people of a racial group they did not want on the jury. That is not right.
There are ways to make the jury selection process fair, ways to free the process from racist abuse. It is unfortunate that the report of the Law Reform Commission on ethnic minorities and the justice system appears to have been another casualty of this government's attack on independent thought in this country.
That is why the government got rid of the Law Reform Commission. That is why it got rid of the Economic Council of Canada. That is why it cut the Science Council. That is why it got rid of the Court Challenges Program. The government does not want independent thought. By independent thought I mean thought that
June 12, 1992

would challenge the in-house positions of government departments.
With a report such as this one, we might be able to make these changes in the jury selection process. It is not going to be easy. It will have to take some real thought to tackle this matter and that is why we needed that report.
There are suggestions on how to deal with other aspects of trial procedure and policing in the report. In particular, during the discussion of this specific bill, it would be nice to have completed the report.
There may be some useful directions from that report however. There is already a suggestion for a study of the use of peremptory challenges including the frequency of their use and reasons for an effectiveness of their use, particularly in relation to minority prospective jurors. There are in fact useful recommendations regarding the use of challenge for cause as opposed to peremptory challenge, and that is what the government should focus on.
We should be looking at these recommendations now, not in another 12 years from now when another Supreme Court of Canada, after going through all this expensive litigation, tells Parliament to make this justice system fair.
At about the same time the Law Reform Commission first recommended the stand asides for the Crown be abolished, the recommendation 12 years ago that foresaw the Supreme Court ruling that has pushed the government to bring forward this bill, a justice of the Ontario high court denied defence counsel for a black accused challenge for cause involving questions relating to prejudices against black people. The reasons given were that to allow such questions would have admitted to a weakness in the nation and a community which should not be acknowledged.
These are still strange goings on in the justice system in this country. Times have changed and today we are forced to acknowledge that weakness. The evidence of a system-wide injustice demands it. We should not be satisfied with a bill that simply reflects the recommendations put forward 12 years ago in an environment that commonly included rulings that turned a blind eye to racism, the kind of rulings we look upon with horror today.
Government Orders
We should be working on a bill that will create the kind of jury selection process that will serve us well into the future, that will ensure our justice system upholds the principles of fairness and equal treatment before the law that we value so highly.
Before I sit down I want to tell the government that one government in Canada has committed itself to eradicating racism in the justice system and changing procedures that foster it. I am speaking about the recent comments of the attorney general of Ontario, Howard Hampton. He is to be congratulated for those comments.
The commitment includes the formation of a race relations unit in the ministry of the attorney general to implement anti-racism training aggressively and to hold the ministry accountable for rapid progress on race relations initiatives. What is the federal government doing in this area? Nothing.
While there is much the provincial governments can do to improve the jury selection process, including amending their own juries acts, because the juries acts are provincial acts, in each province they could amend it for that province to ensure that a broad representation of society is available for jury duty. The attorney general of Ontario is calling upon his federal counterpart to eliminate any possibility that visible minorities are being excluded without cause as jurors at criminal trials. He has asked the Minister of Justice to look at the entire way in which criminal juries are selected, including the ability of counsel to disqualify jurors at trial other than for valid causes.
I suggest that the attorney general of Ontario is on the correct path here. He is talking about looking at the peremptory challenge in the jury selection process in a new and innovative way. Why is the federal government not doing it? Why is this House not doing it when we are looking at this bill? This is not a bill we should be rushing through.
The federal equivalent would be on the right path by calling upon the Law Reform Commission to complete the study and to see how we make changes at the federal level, but the government has not done that.
I will conclude there saying that the bill does have to go through. The reality is that we have to meet the timetable of the Supreme Court, although we could go back and ask for changes. I asked the government about

June 12, 1992
Government Orders
that and asked for an extension of time, but the government is not about to do that.
Reluctantly and I say reluctantly-when I started on this bill it was not so reluctantly-I was quite prepared to see the bill pass veiy quickly. Indeed a New Democrat, the member for Brant, chaired the legislative committee and pushed the bill through in record time. I had been prepared to let the bill go through like that.
The more I began to see what else is involved, the more I began to see that we are behind the times on this. We are reacting. We are not up to date. We have a problem of racism in the justice system, especially as it affects aboriginal people and black people. We should look at it. One area to look at is the jury selection process.
I urge the government to complete that study and not put the onus on us to go back to a committee. "We will go back to the committee. We will do that". I ask the government to complete the study that was being done by the Law Reform Commission, to be careful about doing it in-house because it gets warped inevitably by a government constitutorial point of view, to try to do it from an outside consultant and make it public so that we can debate it in this House of Commons and that a Toronto Star reporter does not have to go and dig out this thing. It should be out for all people to see.
Having said that, we will not put up any other speakers and will let the bill go through now.

Madam Speaker, I will be brief.
My colleague from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception has already indicated that our party will be supporting this bill. My colleague from the New Democratic Party who just spoke has had a lot of experience with juries. I would like to to reinforce some of the points he was making.
Juries have taken a very bad rap recently because of the decision in Los Angeles. An awful lot of people and most of us in this House feel that the decision was completely unfair in the matter of Mr. King. There was untold havoc, pain and suffering inflicted because of the representation of the jury that heard the case outside of Los Angeles.
I feel it is worth making the point that when you have 12 of your peers judging the matter, if there are 12 representative men and women, in my experience you are going to get a better decision than when it is one man or one woman sitting on the bench deciding the guilt or innocence of an accused. As somebody once put it, the biases should cancel out on a jury because when it is one individual judging, even if they have been legally trained, they are all products of our environment and they tend to have biases and so on which often tend to work against the interest of justice.
It is very, very important, as the member for New Westminster indicated, that we do everything we can to ensure that the people chosen for jury panels and the people who sit on juries are representative of the community. Had that happened in the Los Angeles case-I believe all the jury members were white except for one-we could have avoided an enormous tragedy and a setback for the jury system in a neighbouring country.
I appreciate that the jury act in the provinces is the primary legislation dealing with that. There are fewer and fewer of us who are lawyers in this House and I am sure that everyone else will agree with that. Those of us who have watched panels come into courts and who have seen often how unrepresentative they are would identify with the view that we must ensure that in a community in northern Alberta, for example, or the Vancouver area justice not only be done but is seen to be done by the representation of the people who are called for jury duty.
As my colleague just indicated, more work needs to be done on this matter. I am sorry I was not on the committee that looked at this bill. I must say that I do not see that it does very much about the problem that seems to be the central problem which is that juries do not reflect the demographics and so on of the communities they should represent.
I will close by saying that I hope more work will be done both at the federal and the provincial levels to make sure that in future, wherever jury trials are held in Canada-they should be held as often as possible, not as rarely as possible-those called for jury duty will be fully representative of the men and women in the community in which the case takes place.
June 12, 1992
Madam Speaker, I thank the hon. member. Both of us were Crown counsel together, perhaps at different times. He was first in Vancouver.
Many years before.

I know my colleague has also been a defence counsel. He has been through the process.
I am very pleased that he picked up a point that I really missed and that is how good the jury system is. It is one of the great inventions of Anglo-Saxon culture, going back years and years.
It stood the test of time by and large and it can still stand the test of time. I agree with what the hon. member said and I am glad he said it. I am glad he mentioned the King case because it is giving juries a bad name. He put his finger right on the button, if you like, by saying for the jury system to really work it has to represent the community and that means it has to represent all aspects of people in the community and not exclude people. If it represents all aspects, it tends to convict the guilty and acquit the innocent. It can even be ahead of society, as the Morgentaler juries in Quebec were. It is a real protection both for the accused and for society.
That is why it is important that when we have an opportunity like this, as my hon. friend said, we could do so much more. I am thankful for his comments and I am sure the government was listening. At least I hope it was.

Before I begin, I again want to let the House know that motions, that is, proposed amendments with regard to Bill C-55, total 112. Over 80 of those were received the day before yesterday and the rest were received by six o'clock last night. Members will understand that is, again, a very heavy task for the table officers and there have been attempts made to discuss these rulings I am giving with the concerned members. I hope those discussions have been satisfactory. However, it may be that because of the numbers of motions and the limited time, discussion has not been as extensive as some members would have wished.
However, my duty now is to bring to the House the consequence of my deliberations.
Therefore, I am prepared to give a ruling on Bill C-55, an act to amend certain acts in relation to pensions and to enact the Special Retirement Arrangements Act and the Pension Benefits Division Act.

Madam Speaker, I wish to bring to the attention of the House the fact that June is the month of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, ALS, awareness month.
More commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, it is a fatal, rapidly progressing disease attacking the nervous system. Individuals suffering from this devastating disease become completely dependent on their families and friends for their every day needs.
The ALS Society has been working diligently over the last 15 years to help improve the quality of life for the ALS patients and their families, and to find the cause and cure of ALS. To mark ALS awareness month, the society will be handing out replica cornflowers in return for donations toward medical research.
I salute this fine organization and its many volunteers, and would ask all Canadians to help support the important work that the ALS Society does.

Madam Speaker, I rise today to wish Canadian Muslims "Eid Mubarak".
Eid is a three-day religious holiday in the Muslim religion, an equivalent to the Christian Thanksgiving, during which Muslim families all across Canada will donate food to those in need.
This humanitarian gesture commemorates for Muslims the ritual sacrifice of Ishmael by the prophet Abraham.
The Muslim community was established in Canada at the turn of the century with the immigration of a few hundred Lebanese Muslims. The first mosque was built in Edmonton by that community in 1935. Since then the Canadian Muslim community has grown to encompass more than 400,000 members from all over the world.
The diversity of races and cultures within the Muslim community is a testament to the Canadian dream of multiculturalism.
On the occasion of this Muslim religious holiday and Canada's 125th birthday, I want to thank the Muslim community for the contributions they have made to Canada over the past century and wish them success in all their endeavours.

Madam Speaker, on behalf of the Hon. Charles Mayer, Minister of State for Grains and Oilseeds, it is with deep regret that I inform the House of the death of Canadian Wheat Board Commissioner Bill Smith.
Mr. Smith died as a result of an accident while he was on a trade mission in China.
Bill Smith had a distinguished and extensive career that began on his family farm in Alberta. He was employed with the Alberta Wheat Pool where he provided invaluable service. His many achievements and his contributions to the agricultural industry led to his appointment as a Commissioner of the Canadian Wheat Board in May 1983.
Bill was very active in international marketing and developing an expertise in his marketing relationships with a number of Canada's customers including China and Russia, two of Canada's major purchasers. He will be sadly missed. This marks a great loss for his family, his friends, the agriculture industry and Canada.
I would like to offer my personal sympathy to his wife Kathy and their children and their families.

Madam Speaker, one of the things that Canadians can always take pride in is the leadership role this country exerts. Whether it is through the Commonwealth, the Francophonie or the United Nations, Canadians can always be counted on to exert a positive influence, and that role is obvious at the United Nations conference at Rio.
As you know, there have been no shortage of critics of the earth summit, yet one thing is clear, Canada's Prime Minister has done everything possible from the beginning to make this environmental conference a success. When other world leaders dithered on whether they would take part in the conference, our Prime Minister stepped forward and said he would be there.
When the United States said it had problems with the biodiversity convention, our Prime Minister again stepped forward to make it clear that Canada would sign. That kind of leadership in the environment has wide-ranging consequences. Among them is the fact that it encourages other like-minded countries to lend their support to important environmental initiatives.
Every Canadian can take pride in the role that Prime Minister Mulroney has taken in the area of the environment.

Madam Speaker, Inuit from Nunavut who are concerned about the Great Whale James Bay II hydro project met in Ottawa this week. They are concerned because so far the federal environmental review of this proposed project has largely excluded them, yet they will be directly impacted by this project.
At particular risk is the community of Sanikiluaq located on the Belcher Islands in Hudson Bay. Sanikiluaq is situated almost directly opposite the Great Whale River, a mere 90 miles from the outfall from the project.
The Keewatin region coastal communities of Arviat, Whale Cove, Rankin Inlet, Chesterfield Inlet, Coral Harbour and Repulse Bay will also be impacted. The marine environment of Hudson Bay is the traditional food source for the Inuit people of all these communities. The environmental threat to these marine resources is real.
I urge the federal government to fully include the Inuit of Nunavut by funding them in the environmental review process. Without the full and sufficiently funded participation of the people of Hudson Bay and its western coast, the review of this project will be incomplete.

I would like to ask the Minister for International Trade about his trip to Washington this week to meet with U.S. trade representative Carla Hills. The minister was supposed to convince his good friends in Washington to intervene with the American steel industry so that Canada's steelmakers would not be the victim of a vicious American steel war.
Could the minister confirm that all he got in Washington was a great big American kiss-off?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Tirade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not quite sure what my hon. friend means when she uses that expression.
I did have a discussion of this matter with Mrs. Hills. I expressed very strongly the concern we have in the
June 12, 1992

Government of Canada about the impact of the actions that could possibly be taken by the U.S. steel industry. She indicated that she is continuing discussions with the industry. I asked her to make sure that these views would be conveyed to the industry.
As my hon. friend knows, if members of the private sector in Canada or the United States wishes to institute a trade action it is within their power to do so. If the Canadian steel industry wanted to initiate an action against the U.S. industry I am sure she, representing a steel city, would not want me to step in and tell the steel industry exactly what it should do. She would expect that I would convey views of other countries, which I would hope Mrs. Hills would be doing. More than that I think would probably be inappropriate.

I can tell him that what I intend to continue to do on behalf of the constituents and the workers in my riding is to stand up for the Canadian steel industry against an unfair, unfounded U.S. complaint that has already cost Canadian jobs and is going to cost further Canadian jobs.

I am getting to my question. We already know that Canadians are losing out to other suppliers. U.S. customers are reluctant to rely on Canadian suppliers because of the trade war that might start as early as next week.
What specific action does the Canadian minister intend to take to at least urge the U.S. administration to approach the U.S. companies directly, in order to stop this useless trade war which will cost us thousands of Canadian jobs in an industry that is already hard hit?

hope that as a result of our meeting, Ms. Hills will discuss those problems with the industry.

Madam Speaker, the position of the Canadian government may be very clear. The fact is that Carla Hills told the minister to take a hike. She has no intention of intervening to get the message through to American industry.
Since the Minister for International Trade failed miserably in his mission last Thesday, I would like to ask the minister whether he is prepared to call upon our Prime Minister because we know the clock is ticking on this one and there could very well be action taken as of next week, formalized action.
Will he ask the Prime Minister of Canada to have a chat with President Bush while in Rio, to take 10 seconds to try to help save thousands of Canadian jobs, to stop this steel war before it starts, not after the fact when it will be too late?

The position we have taken all along, whether it was when the Prime Minister met with the President earlier this month or late last month I guess it was, was the position the Prime Minister took with the President.
As the Prime Minister has said on other occasions, these are issues that are initiated by the industry. We cannot stop what industry wants to do. We can make our views known, and these views have been made known very, very clearly. We will continue to do so on every occasion that we have.

Oral Questions TRADE

Madam Speaker, the fact of the matter is that Canada's special relationship with the United States just is not working.
I have another question for the same minister. The GATT report released yesterday on Canada's trade policies concluded that Canada's present recession has been prolonged because of its overdependence on a single country for its trade. In fact, Canada's share of total world trade has declined from 5 per cent to 4 per cent under this government.
Why is Canada so intent on tying our trade to one single country rather than expanding our trade to other markets around the world like these GATT countries are telling us?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Hade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Madam Speaker, my hon. friend has distorted the facts. The facts are that Canada has not suffered because of the free trade agreement. Our exports to the United States in the first quarter this year were at record levels. They are at record levels in total.
What about jobs?

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
My hon. friend from Edmonton asks: "What about jobs?" Surely he can understand that every billion dollars worth of trade adds
15,000	jobs. If we add $5 or $6 billion of trade we get somewhere between 75,000 to 100,000 new jobs in Canada that would not be there without the free trade agreement.
Where?

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
My hon. friend asks where they are. They are in her city. I could give her some specific examples of companies that have increased their market share and have created jobs in Canada because they are taking advantage of the opportunities ' that are there with the free trade agreement.
My hon. friend suggests that we are becoming too reliant on the United States market. One of the considerations in entering into a free trade agreement with the United States is to expand into that U.S. market, build our competitive position by increasing our competitiveness through rationalization and specialization into the
U.S. market and use that position to increase our sales into other countries. That is precisely what is happening.
Companies are gaining market share in the United States. They are using that increased competitiveness to sell into other markets.

Madam Speaker, what I am telling the government and what I am telling the minister is that other countries around the world are telling Canada that it is too overdependent on a single economy and that it will be disastrous for this economy.
Although the Asian bloc accounts for some 60 per cent of the world's population and 50 per cent of global production, Canada only does 11 per cent of its trade with Asia. It is incredible, but since 1988 our share of exports to Japan and to Europe have been declining.
Why is this government preaching competitiveness and preaching globalization yet at the same time increasing the integrating of our economy with one single country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the simplistic conclusions that my hon. friend is drawing demonstrate clearly his total lack of understanding of how companies and countries build their competitive positions.
If my hon. friend looked at the statistics and read them honestly into the record, he would see that the reliance on the United States market started back in 1980. At that time our percentage of exports to the United States market was at about 65 or 66 per cent. They reached a peak in the middle eighties of close to 80 per cent. They have come down to 75 per cent.
The precise approach we are following is to increase our trade promotion activities into other countries. I have personally led trade missions to China, Japan and Korea. I will be in other parts of the Far East in September this year and also in Spain, the Middle East and the reforming countries of the former Soviet Union.
These are the efforts the government is taking to broaden our trade but we need a competitive position. The best way that we can build that competitive position is by rationalizing and specializing in the United States market. With access to that market companies are able to do so and are doing so right now.
June 12, 1992

Madam Speaker, as Minister of State for Seniors, I have the pleasure and honour to remind all of us assembled here that at this time of the year, seniors are honoured all across Canada.
From the end of May until the end of June, all provinces and territories have ongoing activities for seniors. These activities, organized at the community, municipal or provincial level, vary from social gatherings
June 12, 1992

to officially designated events, such as the Seniors Day in the Manitoba legislature.
I am particularly happy to take part in this tribute to our seniors. As you already know, the mandate the Prime Minister entrusted to me as Minister of State for Seniors is to give a voice to seniors in cabinet and to represent their interests in Parliament.
Very early in my mandate, I decided that one of the most important contributions I could make was to become a good listener. Consequently, I have spent many hours consulting with older Canadians from coast to coast and in our northern territories. I have also talked with those who represent seniors' organizations, with self-help groups and with individuals who work with older Canadians.
The government has also commissioned a number of studies to learn about seniors' views and we can now rely on the results of two interesting studies.
The first, conducted by Statistics Canada, explored issues affecting the independence of older Canadians. The topics addressed included: preparation for retirement, employment, physical and social activities, health and well-being, life experience, mobility and travel, accidents and safety, housing, income and finances, and satisfaction with life.
The second study, by Health and Welfare Canada, was a series of focus groups exploring the meaning of independence and quality of life for older Canadians. This research and my extensive contacts with seniors have enabled me to understand what seniors expect. They expect independence, equality and recognition as individuals.
For Canada's seniors, independence is both a state of living and a state of mind. Independence, for seniors, means being free to do what they want to do, being responsible for their own initiatives.
Aging is indeed a life long process which involves a series of changes from birth to death, but unfortunately many misconceptions and myths on this subject persist.

Canada's seniors expect to be integrated into society, not seen as a group apart. They want to be treated as equals. They want people to take their views into account, to listen to them and involve them in decision-
Routine Proceedings
making. They want to have the opportunity to participate directly in the design and implementation of programs that affect them. They want to be seen as contributors to society, not as yesterday's corporate leaders, retired teachers or mechanics.

Seniors also want to be recognized as individuals, as different from one another. They do not want to be viewed as a statistic, an age group. I find these expectations very reasonable. Canadian seniors vary in income, cultural and educational backgrounds, state of health, and life experiences. They have different aspirations and fulfil themselves in many different ways. While they have many common concerns, their priorities and opinions differ.
Administrators, health care workers and elected officials often ask themselves how they can best help seniors achieve and maintain this desired independence.
In Canada, we have a number of supports available to seniors. The first major program for older Canadians began in the late 1920s, when the federal government co-operated with various provinces to finance a joint old-age pension scheme. Today, our government's concern for seniors is reflected in the fact that Canada's "elderly benefit system" is now the largest program expenditure area within government.
The rapid increase in the senior population has stimulated the development of other federal programs and services for seniors in such areas as housing and health and social services.
Worthy of special mention is the Seniors Independence Program designed to help seniors improve their health, well-being and independence and to enhance their quality of life. This program encourages seniors to get involved in designing and carrying out projects which affect their quality of life and independence.
New Horizons is another program that has encouraged and supported projects planned and carried out by seniors themselves.

In concluding, I would like to build on our experience in developing a new strategy that also promotes improved co-operation between departments and in-

June 12, 1992
Routine Proceedings
creased partnerships with the various interest groups, including seniors themselves.
I think you will agree with me that in a world concerned with preserving the environment and making the best use of resources, it will be unacceptable to ignore the experience and knowledge of seniors.

Like many other cultures in the world, let us give our seniors the place they deserve.
I encourage hon. members to take part in Seniors Month and to respond to the aspirations of all of these people who have helped build our vast country.
[English)

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to respond briefly to the statement made by the minister.

Needless to say, we all listened attentively to what the minister had to say and we support the wishes that she expressed today.
Personally, I would have some things to add. This statement is off the cuff. I would like to tell the minister that I spent almost all my life with seniors, since I was raised by my grandmother, my grandparents. Every time I hear something like what the minister said, I remember those childhood years.

There is no doubt that for many of our seniors the greatest enemy, if I can refer to it that way, is solitude. To that extent, programs such as New Horizons and others have contributed to getting seniors together in order to counter that solitude that so often affects our senior citizens.
It is regrettable, though, that quite often those seniors we would want to make part of a group of other seniors are often the ones who are the hardest to approach. They live perhaps in more remote areas, not in our cities and towns, or they sometimes have lived alone for a long time and they are hesitant to join groups of other seniors.
Our golden age clubs, our seniors' clubs, have succeeded in large measure in bringing the seniors together and organizing good, sound recreational activities, both physical and otherwise, in order to occupy the time of many of our seniors who have retired, particularly those living alone.
One should not stereotype our senior citizens as people who have necessarily all retired and are living alone because that is not the case.

Many seniors, of course, live very productive lives and contribute to the labour force, directly or indirectly. I for one am glad to see that the old way of looking at things, of forcing seniors to retire at 65 or some other arbitrary age, is disappearing or observed less and less.
The time has come when Canadians must consider our seniors as people who are as much a part of society as those who are younger and, of course, we must consider them as full members because they contribute so much.

Another thing we should consider in all of this is the aging of our work force. We must ensure strong and meaningful participation for our people who have reached some of those milestone years in their lives. They are needed components of our work force and elsewhere.
In a study I participated in some years ago about skilled trades people in Canada we were noting that some of our skilled people, machinists, skilled people in other specialized areas, were all approaching that so-called age of retirement we use to talk about a lot.
If all those peoples did retire at that arbitrary age, which granted is disappearing now, their retirement would have meant that others would have lost their jobs because they were the team leaders, the organizers, the high-tech people, the machinists, the trades people on whom others depended.
Sometimes some will say, wrongly, that if so and so retired, that would make room for the rest of them to go up that ladder. Perhaps there are occasions when that may be so, not that it would make it a credible argument. In many cases the exact opposite is true.

Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure to rise today on this occasion on behalf of my party and our critic from Beaches-Woodbine, the seniors critic for our party, and express my congratulations to the minister on her statement today. It is my pleasure to be able to be part of a statement in the House of Commons, pointing out to the people of Canada and to anybody else watching the parliamentary channel the resource we have in Canada; namely, our golden agers, our seniors.
One of the things that has been brought out in the speech by the Minister of State for Seniors, and it is an important one, is the need for seniors to be and to feel they are independent.
Independence comes from a sense of economic wellbeing, a sense of security in the knowledge they are surrounded by friends, acquaintances, and that they have sufficient funds squirrelled away, if you will, to see them through their golden years.
When I look at the aspect of aging in the reports of Statistics Canada and others I see that 57 per cent of seniors, those over 65, are women. As it gets up into the higher age groups, those percentages increase. We look at the report of Statistics Canada and we see that women
Routine Proceedings
are more likely to be single, widowed and living alone and independently and that fewer women own homes than their male counterparts.
I also look at the recent study by Statistics Canada on aging and independence and see that in the ages 65 to 69, 18 per cent of males have incomes under $10,000. Of those females over the ages of 65 to 69, the figure is 48 per cent having incomes under $10,000 per year. When I speak of independence and the economic well-being that goes with independence, I point to those figures as an area that we as parliamentarians must look at carefully in deciding the course of our legislation and our thrust for seniors in the future. I know this minister has been one who has worked hard on behalf of seniors throughout the time I have been here and I have appreciated her forthrightness with me and others regarding seniors.
I want to point out that all has not been rosy throughout the time I have been here. As seniors critic for my party and as one who has been interested in the problems of seniors, I have noted health care cuts to various provinces, including my home province of British Columbia. Seniors tell me the GST has hurt them enormously in a number of ways that were not thought of when the GST was brought in. The clawback of old age security has hurt them.
One thing that has been brought out very graphically to me is that as people get older they need various other hygienic products. In one recent case, I am aware those particular products cost an elderly gentleman over $200 a month. There is no tax deduction and there is no way he can get these products under his pharma-care program. It is an out of pocket expense.
I know all of us as parliamentarians have had calls flooding into our offices since April 1 from seniors who get Canada pension, advising that their over all income has dropped by $8 or $9 a month.
For many of us who make reasonable salaries, $8 or $9 a month does not seem that significant. However, when you are receiving under $10,000 a year and you are scraping together enough money to be able to eat properly, $8 a month may make the difference between three full meals in a month. It can make the difference if you want to get out and see a friend that month. I want to highlight that.

June 12, 1992
Routine Proceedings
Although this is a time to celebrate with seniors and draw attention to seniors, I do not think we can turn our backs on the problems that seniors have. There are also other areas we must look at.
I have travelled across the country as the seniors critic. We speak about independent living. As medical breakthroughs come along, people are living longer, but we do not seem to have proper facilities for people that require them, the wandering confused, those with Alzheimers disease, those who have had strokes that have rendered them incapable of looking after themselves. We are just starting to be able to properly and adequately look after these people. When you speak to people who have experienced the trauma of having to place their loved one in a home, it is essential that we have those homes for people and make those facilities available.
I point to the Hardy View Lodge in Grand Forks which just celebrated its 10th anniversary as an example of one that has made a community effort out of this.
I want to mention in closing that I know the minister has worked hard and I know there are many things she would like to do that cannot be done. One thing I want to emphasize as we proceed with the celebration of Seniors Month, is that we have to ensure there is more research and development done in the area of aging, gerontology and the whole process of growing old. We know that it happens. However we must deal with some of the results of aging. I want to congratulate the minister. I want to congratulate the seniors for all of the things they are doing this month. It has been a pleasure to speak on behalf of my party in this celebratory month for seniors.

He said: Madam Speaker, it is an honour to be able to rise to put before the House today this group of amendments to federal pension legislation in Canada.
The fundamental purpose of these amendments is to ensure basic fairness, equity, and justice for thousands of Canadians who are currently denied that in this country.
June 12, 1992

The amendments would amend five pieces of federal legislation which deal with federal pensions: the Public Service Superannuation Act which is the pension plan that currently covers some 312,000 federal government employees; the Canadian Forces Superannuation Act which covers nearly 88,000 Armed Forces members; the RCMP Superannuation Act which covers some 20,000 RCMP members; the Members of Parliament Retiring Allowances Act which covers that pension plan for members and senators; and finally the Pension Benefits Division Act which provides for the division of benefits if a marriage or common law relationship breaks down.
We are talking about tens of thousands of Canadians who are affected by this legislation. Among those tens of thousands of Canadians are lesbians and gay men who are involved in committed loving relationships.
Current federal pension legislation does not explicitly preclude the possibility of the survivor of a lesbian or a gay man within the scope of the legislation being eligible for a pension. However, Bill C-55 would explicitly amend these statutes to make it clear that we would be denying access to benefits to couples involved in lesbian or gay relationships.
We have been told the federal government is reviewing all federal legislation to determine whether distinctions which are made with respect to spouses constitute a violation of the equality rights section of the Charter of Rights based on discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
We have been told the results of that review will be available in June 1993.1 therefore have to ask, why is the government now moving ahead to explicitly close the door to equality and justice for lesbians and gay men in this countiy who would otherwise be eligible for such pensions?
I would note the Government of Ontario recently extended a series of job benefits to same sex partners of government employees, but the government was told because of current federal pension legislation it could not extend its pension scheme to lesbian and gay employees within provincial jurisdiction.
I would argue the amendments which are being proposed in Bill C-55 violate the Charter of Rights because they deny fundamental equality on the basis of
Government Orders
sexual orientation. The purpose of the amendments which I am placing before the House at this time would be to repeal the explicit reference to families being of the opposite sex and would in fact leave open the possibility that these pension benefits would be available to lesbians and gay men involved in committed relationships.
I would have preferred to have put in amendments which explicitly and clearly set out that entitlement, but I was told such amendments would be out of order.
I would note as well that some six years after the government promised to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation, we are still waiting for that basic justice, for that promise to to be fulfilled.
Meanwhile the courts have ruled in a number of instances. The British Columbia Supreme Court ruled that a gentleman there, Mr. Timothy Knodel, was entitled to health care benefits. In fact, the provincial legislation which governed the Medical Services Commission discriminated because it did not extend benefits to same sex partners. The judge noted that the two men in question were deeply committed to each other emotionally and sexually, exchanged vows and rings in a private ceremony, established a home together, pooled their finances and shared bank accounts and credit cards.
She noted that evidence in the case by psychiatrist Michael Myers pointed out that the type of emotional bond between homosexual couples is no different than that between heterosexual couples.
Others have made similar arguments, the case of Haig and Birch before the Ontario high court, Brian Mossop whose appeal was recently heard by the Supreme Court of Canada, seeking one day of bereavement leave to attend the funeral of his partner of some 11 years.
I would note as well that we are not talking about a major cost here to the Canadian taxpayer. Indeed, it has been estimated by Mr. Bernard Dussault who works with the federal government in this area that the costs would be minimal. In fact, Mr. Dussault who is the Acting Chief Actuary for the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions in Ottawa has said that it would add, based on the maximum possible estimate, some 1.5

Government Orders
per cent to the over-all cost of the pension plan if all those who were eligible claimed their benefits.
Similarly, Jim Egan and his partner Jack Nesbit, over 40 years together in a committed, caring relationship have been told that in the eyes of the law their relationship does not exist. Others have moved for justice in this area. In fact, I would note that a number of jurisdictions, including the city of Toronto, the Government of Ontario, the Regional Municipality of Ottawa-Carleton, the city of Vancouver, the city of Montreal, the government of the Yukon, a number of universities and a number of major unions have moved in this respect.
Frankly, I as a gay man and as a member of Parliament am tired of hearing that somehow our relationships are not just as strong and just as committed and just as loving and caring as any other relationships in our society, that somehow we are incapable of being families.
In fact, we have heard from REAL Women on this. Peggy Stacey, the president of the B.C. chapter has said: "The traditional family is a mother, a father and children. This ruling affects the fabric of our country". Well, tell that to the tens of thousands of lesbians and gay men in this country who are involved, often against considerable odds, in deeply committed and caring relationships.
I must say that I have seen those relationships, the partners of people with AIDS who have demonstrated incredible love and care and compassion in the course of their struggle against that terrible disease. I think we could learn a great deal from those couples in terms of how to love and build commitment into our relationships.
I would hope that in Canada we will see that it is time to recognize and to celebrate the diversity of our communities, to recognize that lesbian couples and gay couples have been a part of Canadian society, a part of our communities for many, many centuries and to recognize that we too pay taxes. We are not asking for any special rights or special privileges. We are asking for basic equality and basic justice, a recognition of our relationships.
As Dorothy King wrote in a letter to the former premier of Saskatchewan: "Your definition of family is a very distorted one, indeed. If you would care to look outside your own narrow concept of family, you will find an amazing array of family units and many of us, thank
you veiy much, are doing extremely well in spite of the odds against us. My partner and I are just as concerned about our kids as you are about yours. We ski on the weekends, have pets, work, play games, do homework and communicate with each other. When my daughter comes home from school giggling over the cute boy who sits behind her in school, we laugh together and talk about her feelings. She is nine by the way. I do not attempt to make her into anything".
That is one of the many families in Canada. The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that we recognize that in Canada that among the splendid diversity of families in our community are families of lesbians and gay men as well and we should be entitled to full equality. The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that we are entitled to full benefits, pension benefits and survivor benefits. Hopefully this amendment will meet with the approval of the House to ensure that the words of the Charter of Rights in section 15 apply to all Canadians.

Madam Speaker, I just wish to say a very few words in support of this amendment.
This is an important amendment. It is an historic day in this House that the amendment is being discussed and I hope an even more historic day if it is accepted by the government and adopted.
One of the very positive things about our times is that the scourge of homophobia is slowly lifting. It has not completely lifted, but it is beginning to lift. Thus, it brings a freedom with it from a fear which those who are gays and lesbians have had to suffer for years and years and years.
I just wish to say that I give my support and I know that of many, many members of this House to this motion. It is a matter of right, I believe, that this motion be included in this bill and I hope the House supports it.

He said: Madam Speaker, I will be as quick as possible. I know we have a number of amendments today. Basically these Motions Nos. 5, 20 and 39 were put forth to remove what we commonly refer to as the gold-diggers clause in the various pension plans. What it basically does is remove the age 60 limitation on marriages in the Public Service Superannuation Act, the Armed Forces Superannuation Act and the RCMP Superannuation Act. This is for survivor benefits.
Government Orders
The age 60 rule is clearly contrary to the charter on the basis of age discrimination and must be removed. It is also discriminatory because of the changing demographics. I also think it is basically an insult to many of our senior citizens who receive a pension.
If I may be permitted, I will explain what the clause is all about.
For anyone who marries or remarries after age 60, their spouse would not be entitled to survivor benefits unless the person paid extra pension benefits to have those benefits assigned to his or her spouse. That goes back many years ago to the thirties or forties. I do not not have the exact date.
At that time governments felt that maybe people were retiring much older, in their seventies and some in their late seventies. Sometimes they were remarrying and apparently they thought that the remarriage was basically because someone was looking for some type of advantage. The younger person would marry the older person and take advantage of that person with regard to survivor benefits and whatever.
Now with the change in demographics people are retiring earlier. People are remarrying more often, in the sense that there is a higher divorce rate. This would remove that gold-diggers clause.
We had a witness appear before the committee who was a very specific example. He was part of the RCMP for 33 years. He had contributed pension benefits for 33 years. He had remarried because his first spouse had died. He had been married for 12 years. In this case his spouse would not be entitled to survivor benefits unless the person took a decrease in the pension money he was receiving and put it toward survivor benefits in another plan.
It is a reasonable amendment. We have discussed it in committee with the witnesses who appeared. It seemed to have a lot of approval, but the amendment was not put in committee because we wanted it put in the House to explain to everyone exactly what the clause was all about.

Madam Speaker, I would like to rise in support of the amendment. I too was in the committee when this former RCMP officer appeared before it. It was a sad experience to see someone who had devoted his whole life and paid into a pension scheme have his spouse pass away before his retirement and then be told that if he wanted to include

June 12, 1992
Government Orders
his new spouse, even though he had a spouse and paid into the program, there would be extra expense costs to him.
It is an injustice. The amendment that has been put forward is a very realistic one. I realize that there have to be some guidelines as to how it is implemented, but I would urge the government to take this amendment very seriously.

Madam Speaker, I would like to say a few words in support of the amendment moved by the hon. member for Resti-gouche-Chaleur.
At the present time, pensioners who marry after the age of 60 do not have the option of making provision for survivor's benefits. Bill C-55 provides this option, because it allows pensioners to finance such benefits by reducing the amount of their own pension. The excess amount will be used to finance the pension of the surviving spouse.
Whether this puts an end to age discrimination, which goes against Section 15 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, is a very moot point. The Federal Superannuates National Association, with a membership of several thousand retired public servants, supports the principle of extending survivor's benefits in the case of marriages that take place after retirement but does not agree with the proposal that would require pensioners to reduce their own pension in order to provide for survivor benefits.
Since the regulations will be determined later on and we have yet to be advised of any details concerning the amount of such benefits, I think we could reasonably expect the government to support this motion. Because so much depends on the regulations, we are still in the dark about how much it will cost pensioners to finance their pension and how much survivors will receive.

He said: Madam Speaker, the purpose of this amendment is to attempt to increase the survivor benefits on 50 per cent to 60 per cent in those cases where it is needed.
The scope of Bill C-55 does not extend to this particular issue. Legal counsel feels that the only way to bring this issue into the discussion on Bill C-55 is to provide for regulation making power, to provide circumstances in which a surviving spouse or a child of a contributor can get more than 50 per cent of the annuity.
To put it bluntly, it conforms to the benefits standards act which the government tries to make private companies follow. Madam Speaker, I thought members would appreciate a bit of history behind this motion and some consistency with regard to the attitude that the government takes toward public servants.
Since 1984 Canadians have become disillusioned about the political institutions of this country and the whole political process. This has been created and fostered in no small measure by this government's philosophy of do as I say, not as I do.
This hallmark of the present government's approach to public policy matters is evident in Bill C-55. The purpose of the motion before the House at this time moved by my friend from Restigouche-Chaleur is to correct a serious fault in the present legislation.
In 1985 the Canadian government introduced a pension benefits standards bill. This bill which was enacted into law set out a series of minimum standards that Canadian private sector employers required to observe and to follow in setting up and managing pension plans for their employees. This was the government telling the private sector: "Here are the standards".
One of the key provisions of this legislation that affects benefits is the requirement that employers observe the 1966 Canada Pension Plan standard with respect to

June 12, 1992
Government Orders
widows' pensions, namely that as a minimum widows be provided with 60 per cent pensions.
We know at this time that the widows of public servants get 50 per cent of the entitlement. In so far as we are concerned, we have tried over the years to convince this government to stick to its promise of treating public employees, their dependants and their surviving relatives with minimum attention to what this government preaches; in other words a minimum of 60 per cent rather than maintaining the 50 per cent which is presently the order of the day.
The government did not include that in Bill C-55, although it had given the indications in prior communiques, prior declarations or statements that it would.
We are talking of a fairness issue. That is why I wanted to take a few minutes to cover this. If ever there were a longstanding fairness issue, it is to treat our own employees, those who work for the Government of Canada, in the same way as the Government of Canada states the private sector should treat its employees.
I must confess that I have great difficulty in understanding why this bill does not increase widows' pensions from the 50 per cent to the 60 per cent level as promised by the government some time ago.
As I have mentioned, this feature has been in our own Canada Pension Plan for 25 years. It now exists in the MPs pension plan and was made a mandatory requirement for private sector pension plans over five years ago.
I know of no one who disagrees with the proposition that the widows of public servants should not be accorded the same treatment as those of former employees in the private sector.
The government's failure to act on this matter I find even more difficult to fathom given the assurance the President of the Treasury Board gave this House on April 17, 1985. He said: "The Public Service plans will as a minimum generally meet the requirements of the federal Pension Benefits Standards Act". That was a promise, it has not been kept, and we feel it is contributing to this atmosphere of mistrust of politicians by the population.
The only conclusion I can come to is the many words used by the government to express its concerns over the financial plight of older women in Canadian society are just that, nothing but words.
It is equally obvious the government's 1985 promise to correct this human tragedy is turning out to be as empty as many of its other promises to correct long-standing unfairness; unfair processes, unfair programs, unfair application of laws as they affect women.
In this House we should stand up and keep our word to the Canadian public and treat our own employees in the same way we expect the private sector to treat its employees.

Madam Speaker, I want to echo the words of my colleague for Ottawa-Vanier.
There are three points I would like to make. Purely on the issue of fairness, this is a veiy difficult amendment not to support. Purely on the issue of fairness, how do we leave this House and go out and explain to widows they will have to accept less than those in the private sector and other sectors of the Public Service?
Also, it is probably not a good basis for an argument from a logical viewpoint, but from the pure viewpoint of compassion, if there is anytime that compensation is important it is after the death of a loved one. The last thing in the world a bereaved spouse needs is to be in need of funds. This extra 10 per cent allows for flexibility. To the issue of fairness I would add the issue of compassion.
The third point is the one made by my hon. colleague for Ottawa-Vanier. If you make a promise, you should keep it. If you do not know how much it is going to cost, you should not make the promise. But if you make the promise, then you should keep it.
I would find it veiy hard for anybody to stand up in this House and not support this amendment on any one of those three principles.
