He said: Madam Speaker, as everyone will recognize there are a number of motions grouped together here. I will try to be as succinct as possible.
Motion No. 9 deals with interest on the death benefit account. Although this clause of Bill C-55 addressed by Motion No. 9 broadens and clarifies existing unilateral authority of the government relating to the calculation and crediting of interest to the death benefit account, it also proposes that the government will have sole authority in determining the amount of interest earned by the account. This amendment recognizes the preponderant role played by employees and pensioners in financing death benefit payments.
Motion No. 26 deals with the military and with regard to payments. Since military personnel have already made their contributions to their plan for the last quarter of 1990-91 our party felt in all fairness that the government should do likewise instead of giving itself a three month premium holiday. This is where this amendment flows from.
Motion No. 29 also flows from the military as well with regard to employee contributions to the CFSA. Military personnel should have some say in determining the proportion of their compensation in pay benefits and pensions. In this case, the amendment provides that amounts credited to the superannuation account will be decided by the President of the Treasury Board in consultation with the Canadian Forces Pension Advisory Committee. Moreover, these amounts shall be acceptable for a majority of committee members.
Motion No. 27 basically ensures that at least the minimum, the status quo in government employer contributions would prevail until the minister has tabled his studies and has reviewed the pension plan as promised several times over.
Motion No. 28 again is similar but deals with the next plan. The RCMP plan as well has a number of amendments to it.
Motion No. 52 again refers to the benefits and the contributions paid by the members of the plan and is more or less asking the government to put its contribu-
June 12, 1992

tions in rather than giving itself a three month premium holiday.
I believe the others are similar in nature to the other plans. I would maybe want to mention Motion No. 56.
Employers in the private sector cannot borrow from their employees' pension plans. The income tax pension registration regulations and the conflict of interest provisions of the Federal Pension Benefits Standards Act forbid such action. The federal government simply ignores its own laws in this area. The hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier spoke awhile ago about fairness and about the government making rules for the private sector and other sectors, but not following its own rules and not setting a standard for itself.
Motion No. 56 would ensure that the government observes the laws that it has enacted and imposed on the private sector. The regulations relating to the calculation and crediting of interest to the account would be determined in consultation with the pension advisory committee depending on which pension plan we are dealing with. I would ask the government members to review the amendments and I would ask my colleagues from other parties to review the motions as well. I ask for their support.

Madam Speaker, I too would like to add a few words on these amendments. Many of the amendments that are being provided by the Liberal Party at this time I presented when the committee was sitting.
I want to emphasize the importance of these amendments because they are tied very strongly to the bill. We have to recognize that this bill is changing the whole structure of our pension schemes for public servants, for the military, the RCMP, for members of Parliament, for spouses.
The amendments which the member put forward will give some security to these people who are contributing to pension schemes. The government is changing it from legislation to regulation. I think that has to be the context in which we discuss the amendments that have been put forward by the Liberal member-I am not sure of his riding-who has addressed the areas of concern. We should have some teeth in the bill itself so that the government cannot change all the rules through the Governor in Council or whatever group after the bill gets Royal Assent.
Government Orders
I urge the members opposite to look at these amendments in a more serious way. They did not do that in committee-no, I should not say that. There were areas of concern where the public servants came out very strongly with regard to the indexing portions and the Income Tax Act. There were some changes there and I give them credit for that.
I do want to emphasize the importance of some of these changes which are being put forward by both sides and I support the amendments put forward by the member.

Madam Speaker, I would also like to make a few comments and express my support for the amendments to Bill C-55 proposed by the hon. member for Restigouche-Cha-leur.
The Liberal caucus has spent a lot of time and held a number of meetings to try and understand the basic principle of Bill C-55.1 think we made it clear in debate, both at second reading and in committee, that we supported the clauses that will help make our pension legislation fairer and more equitable.
We are in favour of harmonization with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, as I said earlier in my remarks on Motion No. 6, but we strenuously object to the government doing to the Public Service pension plan what others are prohibited from doing.
Let me explain: There are funding: mechanisms in public and private pension plans that are regulated by federal legislation, such as the rate of return on investment. In this case, the rate of return on investments for public pension plans is much lower, over the long-term, than the rate obtained by the private sector, because we are obliged to invest this money at lower rates.
Furthermore, this government is in the habit of borrowing from its employees, in other words, from their contributions to the pension plan, to finance its own requirements.
To date, the government has borrowed $71 billion from the Public Service Superannuation Fund. I am certainly not impressed with the way this government manages our money, when I look at the reports in the Public Accounts of Canada. As chairman of the Public Accounts committee, I think I speak with some credibility.

June 12, 1992
Government Orders
It was debated in committee and in this House whether the government's accounts were indeed credible with respect to pensions, for instance. If I remember correctly, $1,367 billion was used to reduce the national debt, and this was not government revenue. Just the same, that money was used last year to reduce the government's deficit, which would otherwise have been some $2 billion more than it was at the time.

There are several areas of Bill C-65 that go well beyond the changes needed to comply with the income tax regulations. The minister has used that argument over a period of time, saying: "We are just trying to comply with the income tax regulations, which is the law of this country".
Why does the government not say: "We will comply with all the laws of this country, including the Pension Benefits Standards Act which says that you cannot borrow". The private sector cannot borrow from its own pension funds to finance its operations. It cannot do that.
Why can the government do it? I ask that question. It does it. It goes against the laws of this country. It decides what kind of interest it is going to pay on the money it borrows. That again is not allowed in the private sector. Why is it this government does it?
Here we have a bill which was supposed to comply with the laws of the land, the Income Thx Act. The minister has used that many, many times.
Bill C-55 proposes to remove Public Service Superannuation Act provisions that until now have been prescribed by a minimum government-employer contribution, minimum interest that the government must pay on pension funds it borrows and prescribed also in which pension plan deficits are to be amortized.
The government is now proposing that these longstanding provisions be replaced by a regime under which the minister alone decides how much the government, as employer, will contribute to the Public Service Superannuation Act, how much the government will contribute to the RCMP pension plan, how much the government will contribute to the armed forces pension plan.
It will do it by regulation. We do not know what those regulations will say, but I know for sure it will be a
unilateral decision taken by the government without consulting with the pension people or consulting with the joint Public Service Council which oversees many of these things. Pensions, as we know, are not negotiable in the Public Service.
I come back to that principle of fairness. How can this government continue to do things which, in my view, are contrary to the laws of this land, which it forbids the private sector to do? However, it does it. I do not understand. I wish the minister would get up and break the silence of this place this afternoon.
It is only 1.30 p.m. We are going to go on for several hours yet. He can explain to us how fairness applies in this bill, because it does not. I am afraid that this is a step backwards and I am not happy at all with the way we are going on this question.
I would tell my colleagues in the House, it is certainly a step in the right direction to adopt the amendments put by my colleague from Restigouche-Chaleur and I implore members of this House to look at them seriously and to consider supporting them.

Motion No. 59.
That Bill C-55 be amended in Clause 80 by striking out line 18 at

He said: Madam Speaker, we have heard a lot today about the Pension Benefits Standards Act. Basically, these three motions apply to the three different superannuation acts and are the same motion in the three of them. It asks the government to have the Pension Benefits Standards Act apply to those three acts.
It also looks forward at the process where the minister has promised a review and has promised consultation in that review. It would also permit the minister to implement some of the recommendations out of that process without using the excuse that the statute would have to be amended because it does not conform to the Pension Benefits Standards Act.
Again I come back to the fairness issue that has been talked about time and time again here today. The government has made rules that apply to the private sector and it should have to follow those rules as well.
It is a very straightforward, reasonable amendment. It is a reasonable request and it is a matter of fairness. The minister has talked about fairness, therefore the minister and his colleagues should recognize that this is one point they should support.

Madam Speaker, again I want to talk about this amendment in terms of trying to convince the government. I do not think we are making too much headway on trying to do this, but nevertheless we will try again to convince the government to follow its own laws.
As I said, the Pension Benefits Standards Act was a bill of this government and was adopted by this House and it should be, in my view anyway, adhered to by the government.
Absolutely.

I mentioned a few minutes ago that there were longstanding provisions dealing with funding, financing, borrowing, the amount of interest that is paid on Public Service pension plans, be they the public servants, Armed Forces or the RCMP.
Government Orders
What I alluded to in my previous comments was that this bill takes a different tack and allows the government to unilaterally decide and determine how and when the pension plan deficit will be amortized, what kind of interest rates will be paid, what kind of contribution the government will make. In my view, it changes the rules of the game without giving us too much information in terms of regulations that will flow from this.
The levers the government is giving itself could launch a large scale financial raid on Public Service pension funds. Bill C-55, if enacted, will allow the government to pass some of its pension bills to the next government, if I may use that word, for payment. I will explain.
This bill will allow the government to reduce its budgetary deficit at the expense of an increased budgetary deficit for the next government. These proposed changes and their timing also raise serious doubts as to the sincerity of the statements made by the government that it intends to address the serious question and issues raised by the Auditor General in his reports over the years in the way that Public Service pension finances are managed by this government.
The timing of these changes also casts a long shadow of doubt on the minister's promise to carry out a review of the financial and benefit features of the program.
I was privileged today to get a copy of a letter sent recently to the hon. Audrey McLaughlin, PC, MP, in which the government makes an undertaking that it will review the Members of Parliament Retirement Allowances Act after C-55 receives Royal Assent.
The government has promised public servants that C-55 was nothing but a technical bill that was going to give public servants certain advantages that they did not have in the old law. What it does, in our view, is give a few crumbs here and there, but it takes away a lot of things that we believe were important to the pension administration programs of the government.
The implications and the issues that we tried to raise in terms of the management of the funds for example have fallen on deaf ears. The Federal Superannuates Association which presented many briefs to the legislative

Government Orders
committee, for example, made some rather interesting contributions and some positive, I thought, proposals. The head of the group in his testimony to the committee says: "The government's move to propose these changes before these important studies are completed is akin to putting the cart before the horse".
I also agree with the Public Service representatives when they said: "The government's move to give itself full and unfettered authority to do whatever it wants with Public Service pension finances before it carries out promised reviews raises very fundamental questions about the purpose of these reviews". We heard another today, that it is going to review Public Service pensions, but it is also wants to review members of Parliament pensions. Well, it is well time it did. We agree with that, we have asked for that and the people of Canada have asked for it.
However, are we going to be facing the same kind of situation that the cart is going to be put before the horse in terms of here is the government's plan? We decide what is good for Public Service pensions, we decide what kind of interest rate we will pay from now on by regulation and we decide what our contributions will be. Will it again tell the Canadian public that it will decide what members of Parliament will have in terms of pensions, that it will decide God knows when what kind of contributions will be made? Whether we will correct some of the faults in that program which are needed, we agree, is another question.
We received this letter that the minister sent today or yesterday with some apprehensions. We would like to see that start now, but we are not confident that this government will act in a way that will be open, clear, fair and equitable to all those who are concerned. If we rely on what has been done with C-55, we are concerned.
The experience that we are going through at this time is that this government has absolutely no ears for amendments and absolutely no understanding of what fairness is about if it pursues this bill with final approval in third reading and Royal Assent. These amendments that we are studying at this time are important amendments. They only ask the government to comply with the laws of the land. They only ask the government to do what every other company in Canada that has a pension plan has been told to do. It will not create any additional expenditures of public funds.
It does not oblige the government to make any regulations to apply the Public Service Superannuation Act or the other two acts, the RCMP and the Armed Forces.
If the government bought those amendments, if it did comply with the Pension Benefits Standards Act, it would oblige the government to follow the law. It would be in favour of that. It would want to give that kind of an indication by supporting these amendments, by saying it will comply, it will follow the laws of the land adopted in 1985 by its initiative. The government should not try and outwit, out do or out manoeuvre public servants, be they public servants, RCMP or Armed Forces, by having its own regulation in there all the time telling them what we the government thinks is good for them.
All we ask is fairness. We want the government to be fair with its own public servants. We want this fairness to apply to them as it applies to the private sector. We would like to see a commitment that the government will apply the Public Service pension plans to the benefits standards act.

Madam Speaker, I will be very brief. I would like to pursue a little further the comments made by the member for Ottawa-Vanier.
We in the committee tried to get the Auditor General before the committee because in his report he identified some very serious problems with regard to the invest of pension funds and the interest accrued to those accounts and so on.
Here we have a situation in which we on this side of the House are proposing-I did in committee-that there be some protection and some methods of making sure those funds are secure and properly invested and taken through.
By accepting this amendment not only would you be strengthening the bill and making it fairer you would also be carrying out the concerns that the Auditor General had when he looked at the pension structure of public servants.
I would urge the government to take these amendments very seriously.

Mr. Speaker, I have a number of motions here and a lot of them deal with the empowerment of cabinet and the Public Service; higher functions of the Public Service.
Motion No. 11 deals with the government's possible reduction of indexing with the PSSA benefits by regulation. The minister in a letter tabled with the committee promised to make it absolutely clear that this could not be possible.
It is not absolutely clear. In the government's mind it seems to feel that it will not be able to do it without going through statute. Those who belong to the plan are fearful that it is still possible. It is not absolutely clear.
This amendment, and if the government is really sincere about making it absolutely clear, would make it absolutely clear.
Motion No. 13 is an even more serious amendment, not necessarily for all of the persons who benefit from these plans, but for democracy itself.
There are a number of provisions in Bill, C-55, that where there is an inconsistency, the regulations will
supersede the statute. In other words, we could debate here. We have elected members of Parliament who could put forth a law, pass a law, so that it becomes the law of the land. Through regulation, if there is an inconsistency between the regulation and the statute, Bill C-55 would permit the regulation to supersede the statute.
In committee that raised a lot of concern. Some members went so far as to say it was a direct attack on democracy. It is. When the legal counsel was asked whether this was a normal practice, he said it was becoming a normal practice. In other words, the government was trying to run things by regulation. We know what happens with regulations. Quite often they are left in the hands of a few and quite often the regulations change overnight, depending on who and where and what it applies to.
Motion No. 14 would make it very clear. This amendment attempts to make it absolutely clear that the government cannot unilaterally use regulations to change amounts of pensions, annual allowances, annuities, supplementary benefits or lump sum payments.
If this amendment would have been adopted some time ago, after the first meeting of the committee, it would have prevented a lot of the anxiety of the members who belong to these plans. I cannot understand why, when the minister says he wants to make it absolutely clear, he does not make it absolutely clear.
Motion No. 33 is similar because we are dealing with a number of pension acts here. They follow in line. We are trying to standardize them in certain cases. It deals with that provision of regulations superseding statutes where there is an inconsistency.
Motion No. 60 would deal with the indexation again. It would again in this case make it absolutely clear, as the minister wants. I do not know why the government would not accept this amendment. It would make it absolutely clear in the case of the RCMP Superannuation Act that

the benefits would not be reduced through regulation, especially the benefits with regard to indexation.
The government says it is just getting it in line with the Income Tax Act. The Income Tax Act provides for a lot of changes through regulation, so we do not know exactly what we are getting to.
The other thing that was alluded to earlier is that we talk about these regulations as if they are already there, as if we know what they are, but they have not been tabled. I do not even think that we have started that much work on them.
Motion No. 62 deals with the regulation-making power of the government. If this were accepted, it would prevent governments now and in the future-not only this government but other governments as well-to run roughshod over certain acts through regulation.
Motion No. 11 deals with indexing and is with regard to trying to make it absolutely clear, as the minister really wanted to make it clear. Again, we are asking government members to support these amendments.
These amendments are probably the most important ones in the bill at this stage because we talk about regulation. We talk about giving the government all this power through regulation. For the members of the plans, publicly and privately, in committee, in press conferences and in press releases there was the concern.
The government kept on saying it would not do that. We know what it has done. I can assure you that there is cause for concern. If the minister actually does want to make it perfectly clear, he should start with these amendments.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to pursue the amendments I put forward, Motions Nos. 15, 34 and 65.
All three are identical but we have three pension plans here. We have the Public Service pension plan, the RCMP pension plan and the military pension plan affected by this.
I want to start off with regard to clause 30 because there was some veiy, very positive work done. Through the agreement of all three parties, some major amendments were made to the bill. I want to commend not only the government and the Liberals but also the depart-
Govemment Orders
ment that understood fully the concerns that we had in those areas. There were some significant changes made.
The fact is that this is a regulatory bill and we do not know what the regulations are going to be when the bill comes into place. Therefore, I have placed this amendment with regard to clause 30 of Bill C-55.
It says:
That Bill C-55 be amended by adding the following immediately
after line 32 on page 32.
The Governor in Council may not, by regulation made under section 71, reduce or in any way diminish pension benefits that accrue under this act before the coming into force of section 71.
(2) Subsection 71(3) does not apply in respect of subsection (1).
This is a very important amendment. If the government is intent on telling the public servants, the RCMP and the military that it does not want to roll back their pensions or change their pensions, then it will adopt this amendment to ensure that they will not be rolled back.
If it does not accept this amendment, those pensions are in jeopardy because future governments, even if this minister commits that he will not do it, what is to stop a future government, knowing that the regulatory powers are in this legislation, to do the things they want.
I want to urge the government to support this amendment to ensure that the pensions and the provisions that are now in place are protected.

Mr. Speaker, this whole group of amendments deals with a very important point. The amendment debated in committee, as my friend from Restigouche-Chaleur said, was highly contentious because what it proposes to do is give the government the right to do by regulation certain things, not by legislation.
We asked questions about it. I admit in the beginning in committee it was difficult to get an answer from the government. After a while they came to understand that we were concerned about this unilateral power of the government to make regulations affecting the pension plans of public servants, armed forces and RCMP.
We asked them for total assurance that none of the standard benefits, the indexing of the pensions, the contributions made by the employer, et cetera, would be changed by regulations. It took some time. It took about three weeks to a month before we got an undertaking from Treasury Board and the government, and the minister made the commitment that it was not their

June 12, 1992
Government Orders
intention to do certain things by regulation. They intended to follow the law.
I want to come back to the Pension Benefits Standards Act, which people are now starting to understand is wide-ranging legislation passed by this House in 1985 and which, in my opinion, the government is not following.
In addition to legislating minimum benefit levels for Canadian pension plans for the private sector, it sets out in the Pension Benefits Standards Act a code of conduct for pension plan administrators and managers by making it a condition of pension registration that pension plan administrators, and I will read from the act: "shall exercise a degree of care that a person of ordinary prudence would exercise in dealing with the property of another person". It goes on to require that administrators not be in a material conflict of interest.
I for one do not believe that Public Service employees and pensioners are being unreasonable when they ask that the many billions of dollars they have put into their pension plans over the years be protected by the same code of conduct.
Over the years this government has been in the centre of many conflict of interest situations. These conflict of interest involvements have seriously eroded public trust in governments. However, as serious as these conflict of interest scandals have been, in my opinion they pale in comparison with the conflict of interest situation that confronts the government if it refuses to endorse the spirit and the principle of these amendments.
They also pale in comparison to the possibility of conflict of interest that could come from the administration of Public Service pension plans. To use a variation of an expression that has been in wide use in the last few years: this will be mother of all conflict of interest situations.
We have the government refusing to say publicly in this House today that it commits itself by supporting these amendments not to use regulations to change the standards of pension plans of public servants, armed forces personnel or retired RCMP officers or personnel.
I do not understand this. Let me highlight for a few minutes the nature of this conflict of interest. As the sole administrator of Public Service pension plans, the government has a duty to protect the many billions of dollars that public servants and pensioners have put in their pension plans, a duty to get the best possible return on the billions of dollars that are in that fund. There is about $71 billion; a lot of money. The government must do its best to get a return on those billions of dollars in pension funds of the Public Service and RCMP.
On the other hand, as a borrower-and the government it does borrow the money-of that $71 billion, because the government borrows that fund to finance its operations or its deficit, the government has a natural interest in minimizing the interest it pays on those borrowings.
You can see the conflict. Furthermore, the opportunity of the government to short-change public servants and pensioners in this regard is being increased in my opinion by this bill, not diminished. Bill C-55 tightens the monopoly stranglehold of the government on the management of the Public Service pension funds.
The serious nature of this conflict of interest was serious enough that the Auditor General, an impartial person, an agent of this House, a servant of Parliament, in his 1991 report said that the bookkeeping of this government in the matter of pension leaves a lot to be desired. He did not like the way it was keeping its books and he said so. That, in my view, is a serious comment made by a very important agent of Parliament to the effect that the management of the pension fund was not taken very seriously by the government.
Over the years the government has made high-sounding speeches about doing something about conflict of interest situations. Most Canadians would agree that the time for talk in this area is long gone and the time for action is long overdue. I know that we have before this House now a study by a committee dealing with conflict of interest. I hope the government reads it and applies some of it.
I also believe that five years, the length of time since we adopted the Standard Benefits Pension Act, is sufficient time to allow for the government to get its act together and to get out, as it requires everybody else, of
June 12, 1992

the direct conflict of interest it is in managing the Public Service funds. Five years is long enough to make a decision on whether it will or will not abide by the same code of conduct it has legislated for the pension administrators of the private sector.
The situation the government is in was well described by the present President of the Treasury Board in his appearance before the legislative committee on March 17 of this year. Without getting into the question of how much blarney he was spouting that day, I do not consider it to be blarney when he said: "It would look a bit ridiculous"-this is a minister of the Crown speaking-"to ask all pension plans in Canada to conform while our own plans are away offside".
This statement was made in relation to government conformity to the 1992 income tax regulations. I hope the minister would agree the logic of his observations on March 17 apply equally to June 12 and that he will get up in his place and support an amendment which clearly sets out the position of this Parliament that the Government of Canada will not remain in a conflict of interest, but will abide by the laws of the country and follow the laws of the country.
I would therefore urge the minister and his friends on that side to bring the government on side with the code of conduct and other features of the 1986 Pension Benefits Standards Act. That is all we ask and that is all these amendments propose to do.

Mr. Speaker, very briefly, we are debating a number of amendments, one of which is put forward by the member for Kootenay East.

Mr. Speaker, I will speak to the three motions that I put. They are very similar and have to do with the three superannuation acts that we are dealing with, Public Service, the military and the RCMP.
Motion No. 16 deals with remedial action in situations where employees are denied benefits to which they are entitled or the opportunity to exercise rights because they have made bad decisions concerning their benefit options due to some erroneous advice or administrative errors. It gives them a chance of reprieve. Deputy ministers and deputy department heads, senior military, and senior RCMP officers, and also I must add political appointees, have that option right now. If there is removal of benefits or rights because of an error, misinformation or whatever, that can be corrected by the minister once it is pointed out to him or her.
June 12, 1992

The second part of the amendment deals with the problems facing Public Service unions and pensioner organizations when they try to obtain information from the government on the operation of their pension plans. This section would facilitate the obtaining of this information.
We heard the word fairness many times today. In fact I believe the minister mentioned that many times in referring to Bill C-55, that it was one of the objectives.
I say again that senior personnel, senior public servants, senior officers in the RCMP and in the military have this option. There is no reason why the every day person cannot have the very same option.
I will not speak to the three motions as the three motions just follow in line with each superannuation act. I would appeal to the justice that should be in this House. I would say it is only natural that we should accept this amendment.

Mr. Speaker, I too have an amendment that is in this group. My amendment affects schedule II which is the part of the bill that deals with spousal benefits under the legislation.
This is one of the amendments which the committee for spousal and children's pensions survival and related benefits was particularly anxious for the government to accept. There are cases in which there are administrative errors made or in which there is some kind of erroneous advice given and someone loses their rights.
This amendment simply gives to the government the opportunity of making a correction. It gives to the minister the opportunity to take remedial action.
There is not a piece of legislation in the world that is perfect. In our constituencies we all face the problem from time to time where people come in after having been given wrong advice. Perhaps they did not understand the advice very well or the advice was actually incorrect. No public servant can be counted on every day of the week, every week of the year, to be sure of the information they give. They are often hurried. The issues
Government Orders
are complicated. Perhaps the person has not explained the full story. Those of us who are lawyers will probably know those days where we did not ask a key question and it turned out our advice was not as good or as correct as it should have been. That can happen.
All we are asking with this amendment is that the House agree to give the minister authority to take remedial action. What is so hard about that? What is so difficult about that?
I hope that the government will consider this seriously and agree to the amendment.

Mr. Speaker, we are dealing with amendments that could be entitled fairness, fairness in treatment of public servants when they look forward to retiring or have retired.
The amendment before us deals with affording remedial action to employees for many reasons. In my files I have dozens of cases where public servants, either because of ill health, because of bad advice or because of the stress situation they were in at the time, decided to take an option which proved to be the wrong decision. They cannot come back and look and ask for a fair hearing.
Yet deputy heads, senior military RCMP and political appointees, are protected in this bill. If they make a mistake, they can go to the authorities and say: "Change the rules for me". My point is why is it that we do it for deputy heads, senior military, RCMP and political appointees and we refuse to do the same thing for public servants?
It boggles the mind. I call unfair legislation unfair when it treats people unfairly. All these amendments put forth by the hon. members from Restigouche-Chaleur and Victoria ask the government to show some heart and consistency and to come to grips with an issue which is something that we must address, fairness, and treat all public servants equally, be they senior administrators of the government or the average worker.
That is a request which we make in all honesty in the spirit and hope that a government will get off its fanny and do something constructive.

E[e said: Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to enter the debate on this bill and to speak to the five separate motions I had moved all respecting the pensions of members of Parliament. As we are well aware, this is a very controversial area with respect to the bill. These amendments are extremely controversial.
I must say, however, this issue is not a new one for me. It is an issue of longstanding. It is one that has been with me for at least some 15 years, dating back to my days serving in municipal government when numerous constituents came to me and raised matters of pension concerns and particularly raised matters relating to the pensions of members of Parliament.
I have had over those 15 years constant discussion and constant correspondence with constituents who had concerns relating to the pensions of members of Parliament. I will just name one, Mrs. Margaret Hunt, a personal friend and a long-time constituent of mine who constantly over those 15 years among others has raised this issue.
Shortly after the our government took office in 1984, the then President of the Treasury Board introduced legislation to make some modifications in pensions relating to public servants and also relating to members of Parliament. There was a great outcry at that time, particularly from public servants. As a result that particular piece of legislation died on the Order Paper and was never renewed and never pursued.
In fact this is the first time since then to my knowledge that there has been a piece of legislation before the House presented by the government dealing with this particular issue.
When Bill C-55 was introduced the present President of the Treasury Board indicated that he wanted to appoint a review committee or some review body to look at the pensions of members of Parliament. He indicated that orally and he indicated that in a letter, copy of which I have with me that appears to be dated April 2, 1992.
As I understand it subsequently he wrote a letter yesterday-I have a copy which is undated-to the Leader of the New Democratic Party in which he again indicated that he intended to proceed with some sort of an inquiry into the pensions of MPs. At the same time, of course, he did not say when. He did not indicate what the
Government Orders
terms of the inquiry would be or who would be making the inquiry.
It would seem to me, given the concerns that have been expressed about this situation and about the pensions of members of Parliament, it would have been very wise indeed for the President of the Treasury Board to have in fact at the outset of this whole entire debate on this bill set up that inquiry formally so that it would have dispensed with any question whatsoever about where we were going from here, particularly in light of the fact that things can quite logically happen along the way, and they did with the previous government bill which died on the Order Paper.
All members of Parliament know that the public has three main areas of concern, particularly my own constituents, with the pensions of members of Parliament. They include something called double-dipping. They include the whole question of indexation of the pension and they include the question of the age at which the pension begins.
These motions, and specifically Motions Nos. 67 and 68, deal with the issue of double-dipping. Double-dipping means that if an MP is already receiving a pension and then gets another government job of some sort he or she would be in a position of being paid twice for their time. This amendment would put an end to that.
The other motions I have before the House at the moment, Motions Nos. 68, 68C, and 69A, deal with the issue of when the pension begins. speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I was saying the other day in debate on Bill C-227, having to do with the desecration of the flag of Canada, various sources in the legal community have urged the government to exercise restraint in the application of our criminal law. The government has been urged from time to time to use the criminal law only to reaffirm fundamental values. Our Criminal Code should contain only acts which are both punishable and wrong; that is, acts contravening fundamental values and nothing more.
The criteria for real crimes are fairly clear. A real crime in my opinion is an act which is morally wrong and that threatens and infringes on fundamental social values. These values are of two kinds: those which are essential to the very existence of a society and those which are essential to the existence of our own particular society.
Generally, essential values are those without which social life would be impossible. Society is, after all, a co-operative enterprise. Its members must have some give and take, must respect each other's needs and vulnerabilities and must enjoy some mutual trust and reliance.
In other words, they must prefer order to anarchy, peace to violence and honesty to deceit. All social life therefore commits its members to such values as the sanctity of life, the inviolability of the person, the virtue of truth and the necessity of order.
Transgressions against these essential values are crimes of violence, fraud and crimes against peace, order and good government. These are the major candidates for inclusion in the code of real crimes.
June 12, 1992

Besides these generally essential values, most societies hold certain other values. For example, we in Canada set high value on individual liberty. This is by no means necessary for social life, for many societies have existed without it, and an unfree society is still a society but not a society in which we would want to live.
For us, no society would suffice without a measure of freedom, justice, tolerance, human dignity and equality. Transgressions of these important values are crimes such as false imprisonment, interfering with justice and hate propaganda. These form the second category of real crimes.
I also wish to comment on this bill from the perspective of the Canadian Charter of Rights of Freedoms. I think that it is important that members of the House keep the charter in mind whenever considering new legislation. The charter in section 2 sets out the fundamental freedoms which Canadians enjoy. That section states that everyone has the following fundamental freedoms: (a) freedom of conscience and religion; (b) freedom of thought, belief, opinion and experssion, including freedom of the press and other media of communications; (c) freedom of peaceful assembly; and
(d)	freedom of association.
Honourable members will note that paragraph (b) explicitly guarantees freedom of expression. Any ban such as proposed in this bill would have to be considered in light of the charter guarantee of this fundamental freedom.
For all of these reasons, this bill proposes an inappropriate extension of the criminal law. I believe that we should explore more appropriate ways of dealing with such offensive behaviour.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jean-Guy Hudon (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take a few minutes to give you my views on the hon. member's bill, which deals with values and symbols.
I have always been impressed by the changes that take place in society and how our interpretation of certain actions may differ. Today, we have a generation of young
Private Members' Business
people for whom certain symbols no longer have the same value they had for us.
Let me give you an example. Today, a contract is always in writing. Everything has to be in writing, whether it is signed or initialled. I know, because I was involved as a negotiator in the collective bargaining process for quite some time. Today, everything has to be exactly right and somebody's signature has to be on it. A signature commands respect. Although we are now starting to have some doubts about that, because if there were no witnesses or a person had no authority to sign- When we see someone's signature, we immediately start wondering whether they had that authority.
Formerly, it was a matter of giving your word. Our parents and grandparents felt that very strongly. When someone said: "I give you my word or I swear on the Bible", that was sacred. This ritual hardly exists any more. We still see it among some older people, but today, even someone's signature or initial on a letter may be challenged. We saw this recently, even in contracts with native tribes or societies; today, 100 years later, they say that the person who signed the contract, which according to the White man was legal, had no authority to sign. So this has far-reaching implications. My point is that our values have changed.
To me a flag is sacred. There are other symbols that are sacred as well but today we have a generation of young people that has been told, and there is nothing wrong with that, that they must express themselves. Well, they do. The way they do it is, of course, not my way, just as my way is different from my grandfather's way.
Today, we are being ask to vote on this bill and refer it to committee for consideration. I suggest referring the bill to a committee in the departmental envelope, for consideration, because it has implications that are quite substantial. We are talking about a bill that appeals to different values in a different context.
People were told to express themselves, and so they did. We had one example last year, or was it two years ago, when five or six people trampled the Quebec flag. It was estimated that the same scene was shown on television 21 or 22 times. Each time, it was always the same five or six people making the same gesture, which was meant to insult those for whom the flag is a symbol.

June 12, 1992
Private Members' Business
We must be careful here. When we vote for a bill, it has to be votable. Second, it has to be enforceable. By the way, what is a symbol? Then we get legislation that interprets exactly what a symbol is, because we cannot start defining every single symbol. The Canadian flag is a symbol of my country: Canada. But there are provincial symbols as well. There are coats of arms and any number of other ways to symbolize something or other in this country.
Today, thanks to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, we have freedom of expression, which is what I am doing today. We have certain symbols in this country and there are more. Our values and our laws are changing-this legislation, for instance-but we should not let legislation make matters worse.
One of the problems we have in this country is that our communications are becoming increasingly efficient. Although that may be a good thing, there are a number of drawbacks, and some of them are quite harmful. I said earlier that we saw the Quebec flag being trampled 22 times. That is 22 times too many. It should not have been done in the first place. However, it was shown 22 times, with some kind of ferocious glee. Because we have this information overload today, people make up their minds just on the basis of a picture or perception. Of course people weren't in front of their television sets 22 times to find out what they were talking about. When the people involved in the incident apologized, the media showed them, but if you have a television set on and you are cooking or knitting or working on a puzzle or talking on the phone, you don't hear the message. The only message you get is the picture. And you say to yourself: Not again! Even if it didn't really happen 22 times, it was shown that many times on television and that was so many times too many. This is one of the problems we have today. It amplifies problems to the point that they become an irritant to people my own age, to my colleagues here in the back or to younger people. And of course with our own symbols we probably irritate young people as far as some of their symbols are concerned. It is all part of the whole problem.
This bill should be referred to committee for consideration because it contains implications for the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and we need a better definition of our symbols.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate today and I want to speak in favour of the bill proposed by my colleague. I want to congratulate him for bringing it to the attention of the House.
I have a bill myself, presently being drafted, which is similar except it would also cover the flags of the provinces. I share very much the concerns the parliamentary secretary has raised. I totally agree with him.
In the French media we have seen the flag of Quebec being desecrated time after time. In the English media we have seen the flag of Canada being desecrated every now and then. Of course the reverse is seldom shown because what is shown is meant to tantalise whatever audience one is attempting to tantalise.
For that offence to have occurred once was once too many as the member for Beauhamois-Salaberry has said. To have shown one incident 22 times suggesting the incident had happened 22 times makes it that much more unacceptable.

We in this House can take action to try to rectify the situation. Our colleague has proposed a bill today, and I must tell him that I support his initiative. I would like his bill to apply to the provinces as well.

Once the bill does reach committee, and I hope of course it will be passed by this House and go to a parliamentary committee, I hope my colleague who moved the bill and the committee will recommend including the provinces.
There might be a technical difficulty that might be beyond the scope of the bill under our present parliamentary definitions, but with the unanimous consent of the House, I am sure we could report the bill that way and correct it in the way I am suggesting.
I have had a research document prepared by the Library of Parliament as to the constitutional authority we have to legislate in such matters.
June 12, 1992



I note here, for example, that subsection 91(27) of the Constitution Act, 1867 says very clearly that Parliament can pass legislation to protect the Canadian flag from any form of desecration. That is the opinion of researchers working for us in the law and government division of the Library of Parliament. Our expert advisers tell us that the authority to legislate in this area certainly exists, at least under the Constitution Act, 1867.

How did I get into this? Some weeks ago I received a phone call from a constituent of my riding. Unfortunately, I have not had the opportunity to ask him permission to use his name in the House. I will nevertheless read his letter. Here is what the constituent said:
I am writing in reference to our conversation this morning. My family and I were absolutely shocked when we received this advertising in the mail.
The advertising in question is the one I have here:
How can anyone show that little respect for our Canadian flag? We are Canadian immigrants, i.e. are Canadians by choice, not chance and as such we are very proud of our flag. In our opinion this brochure clearly defaces and dishonours our flag and the companies responsible for it should be held criminally responsible for their actions.
I do hope that you will be able to stop further distribution of the brochure and would appreciate it if you would inform us of the results.
This is a letter I received from a constituent. It is in regard to a brochure which I have in hand. I will not put it before the cameras, pursuant to our rules, but I will share it with you. The brochure in question shows a flag of Canada which is half red and half blue.
The reason for it is to show an alliance between Air France and Canadian Airlines. They have a merger for their travel points and will give 2,500 bonus points. In so doing, they display the flag in a manner which I find totally unacceptable. I will share the document privately with colleagues afterwards, pursuant to our rules. I will show them the information so they can appreciate what I am referring to.
I regret having to say it, but other groups do that as well. It has recently been brought to my attention that a group I support very much is using our Canadian flag in an offensive way. It is not a secret in this House I am a supporter of pro-life causes, but I totally disagree with
Private Members' Business
the brochure pro-life organizations have put out. They show a Canadian flag under the heading of the Canadian holocaust and on the Maple Leaf is what obviously looks like an aborted foetus. I must say to that group, a group I agree with, I find it equally offensive, whether it is Canadian Airlines, pro-life, pro-choice or whoever else is desecrating the flag of this great country.
This is the 125th anniversary of Canada. I hope in this year we will at least pass this bill, send it to committee and ask colleagues and experts to review it. Perhaps in some small way we can show the Canadian people we as legislators feel strongly about our national institutions. Perhaps we can show them we care about the future of Canada and about those symbols and institutions that keep us together.
The flag of our country and of all the provinces and territories deserves the respect advocated by our colleague in his bill.
I trust that we will pass this bill on second reading, send it to committee and make changes to include all the provinces and territories of Canada so as to protect their flags too, to ensure that our national, provincial and territorial flags get the respect they deserve.

In doing so, maybe we will contribute in a small way to showing the people of Canada we care about this country.

Mr. Speaker, along with my colleague for Glengarry-Prescott- Russell, I am very honoured to participate in this debate on this private members' motion from my colleague from Scarborough East. He has introduced a very, very timely and important piece of legislation that may well affect all of us in this country in a very positive way.
As members of Parliament, we all receive a large number of Canadian flags to distribute. I am not sure about your riding but I could probably distribute 10 times the number of Canadian flags, the property of the Government of Canada, without any difficulty. A number of things have happened in the past to flags in this country, and not just to our Canadian flag. Some years ago some Canadians from the New Democratic Party in the Manitoba legislature were upset with an American

June 12, 1992
Private Members' Business
activity in Nicaragua and participated in the burning of the American flag in front of the consulate office in Manitoba. I felt very sad this was allowed to happen and no one was brought to task for it, especially since it involved elected members of a legislature participating in a flag burning.
If the law could be extended, all national flags in my view should be protected in this way. It should be an offence because the national flag is a symbol of the country. While some people may have difficulty with certain countries, I do not believe they should have the right to desecrate another nation's flag.
My colleague from Scarborough East tells me well over 80 per cent of Canadians think this is the right thing to do. I resent any member of Parliament asking the Department of Justice if it agrees with this type of legislation. We are the legislators here. I very much want to support this. It is something that should have happened a long time ago. We would not be witnessing things happening now to our national unity where people can use that symbol of unity and try to persuade others across this land in a negative way about what is so very important.
The use of the flag and twisting it in a way is probably also done in very bad taste. My colleague for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell has highlighted this and it should be done more often. speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to speak as a private member and I will only speak for a couple of minutes on this.
This is a very interesting topic and I want to congratulate my colleague for introducing it. Protecting our national institutions and our symbols is very important.
With respect to this bill I would imagine there would be some interesting charter questions on this. I know in the United States the Supreme Court of the United States has ruled on a similar bill. Nonetheless, committee stage would be another opportunity for members of Parliament to have a look at this.
The member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell made an interesting suggestion concerning provincial flags but the point that the member is making here is that we should protect these national symbols.
One of the speakers indicated how important and how appropriate it would be that we would want to do something to protect one of our national symbols in Canada's 125th year.
Heaven knows, there are enough attacks on Canada's institutions and enough attacks on some of those traditions and some of those things that we believe in.
Recently, the CBC ran a program called The Valour and the Horror. In it was a very thinly veiled attack on Canada's role in World War II, an attack on the leadership of Canada's war effort, and an attack on the role that Canada's allies played.
In the example of what happened in the Far East, in Singapore and Hong Kong, that particular program leaves the implication those who ran our allied war effort were either stupid or were just setting up our allies in that part of the world. It goes on to show and talk about the allied war effort in Europe and again portrays the individuals who ran Canada's allied war effort in a very negative way.
One of the unfortunate things about that is I notice the program is now available in libraries. It is in the library in Niagara Falls. This is now available for people to see the portrayal of what Canada did in World War n. That is a shame because Canadians should feel very proud about what Canada did in World War I and World War II.
It is unfortunate that when the National Film Board or CBC spends money, it is in a way that shows these things in a very bad light.
June 12, 1992

I watched part of a program called Tom Alone that was on the CBC. It showed the Mounties, another one of our national institutions, one of our national treasures, one of the legends of the 19th century and it showed a Mountie bullying some young boy. I did not know what channel it was on, but I said to my wife: "You don't have to tell me, this is on the CBC isn't it?"
I just knew it would not be Global. It would not be CTV. It would not be the private network. It would never be an American station because an American network would not show the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in that kind of light.
I knew right away that the Canadian taxpayers would end up picking up the bill for this very negative portrayal of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Of course it was not done in this wonderful story about a boy looking for his father. Toward the end just before the last spike was driven into the CPR, one of the foremen arranged it so the Asian workers who have worked to put the railway together were all blown up in a tunnel.
God knows there have been instances of discrimination in this country but as I say, leave it to the CBC to put together that kind of spin, that kind of presentation, of again one of those things that all Canadians feel good about, the CPR.
One of my colleagues told me years ago that there was a suggestion CBC might do a story on General Brock, a hero from my neck of the woods. I remember my colleague saying he did not want CBC to do anything. Please, please leave some of these heroes alone. Thank you, thank you very much. Do not do anything on General Brock. He knows what a lot of us know and that is any look at this by the CBC would have the usual negative connotation.
One of our members has come forward and suggested we protect the national flag. I know this is a young country and there are very few symbols, very few legends in a country the age of Canada. The Mounties are one of them, the building of the railway is another. Our role in the wars, which Canadians are very proud of, our flag and our national anthem are others. There are few enough in this wonderful country of 125 years.
I commend the hon. member for bringing forward this initiative.
Private Members' Business

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak in support of Bill C-227. It is only fair to respect one of the most noble symbols of our nation and that is the Canadian flag. Look at this country from coast to coast, at the mountains, the valleys, the institutions, the people. There is one single thing that we all think and believe in and look up to as the symbol of Canada and that is our Canadian flag.
My colleague who just spoke was talking about the importance of protecting the institutions. Unfortunately, in his discussion he moved on to attack the CBC. The CBC is a national institution. The CBC has contributed in the past, and continues to contribute to our society as a whole, to Canadian unity and to the well-being of our people.
Attacking, defacing or burning a flag is an assault on the whole nation. It is an assault on the people. It is an assault on the dignity of the nation.
Historically, going back thousands of years, whenever there was a war between two tribes, groups or families, the first thing the winners would do would be to run up their flag. Then they would bum the other tribe's flag. Simply stated, it is a put-down to bum someone else's symbol of pride.
Even now, whenever there is an international dispute between two nations, the winning nation will pull down the flag of the other nation and raise its own flag.
It does not matter whether you look back thousands of years or whether you look at the present situation, a flag of a nation or of a group is a symbol of dignity.
Nothing irks me, hurts me and bums me more inside than seeing someone tampering with the Canadian flag. I say this because it touches me deeply. I get very mad and upset about it, simply because I know what a flag means to the people as a whole, what it means to me and to the people I represent.
What sort of punishment should we give someone who bums the flag? The maximum punishment possible. I say this because anyone who bums the Canadian flag obviously is a vicious and mean person, a person without a backbone, without any kind of respect, a person who believes in vengeance.
My colleague mentioned that we are a young nation. Well, yes, in one sense' of the word we are a young nation, but in reality, no. Historically, Canada has been around for thousands and thousands of years. Since the beginning of this planet Canada has been here. People

Government Orders moved to this land thousands of years ago. Our native people were here. We now have a country with a population in excess of 26 million.
We have a responsibility to respect the law and protect our institutions and the Canadian flag as a symbol of unity and pride.
My colleague did not make any suggestion in terms of punishment. I suggest the person should go to jail and there should be a fine. Ten years in prison, 20 years in prison; if it were up to me, even 100 years in prison would not be enough for anyone who burns or defaces the Canadian flag. This is a betrayal of the country we live in. I know we do not have capital punishment. I do not believe in capital punishment, but it irks me to the point where I would say that someone who defaces the Canadian flag should be put in jail for life. It is an incredible offence. I know it is not my decision, it is the government's decision.
The recent event that took place in our province where people walked on the Quebec flag was reprehensible. That is a provincial flag and it is a symbol of Quebec, just as the Ontario and B.C. flags are symbols of those provinces. This event was highly unfair and I was quite upset about it. Everyone knows the uproar, the animosity and the hurt it caused people. They are our brothers and sisters and part of this great land of ours.
In my final comment, I wholeheartedly support this amendment to the Criminal Code. I do not know if anyone has moved unanimous consent to the House, but if not I would like to move that this bill be adopted unanimously by this House and be passed on to the specific committee to deal with it.

Mr. Speaker, I do not want to prolong the debate, I just want to make a point.
I have noticed in the last couple of years some of the documentation coming out of government offices has been defacing the Canadian flag as far as I am concerned in my interpretation. Quite often what I have noticed is that the Canadian flag is no longer red. The government has intentionally coloured it blue.
I will give a very specific example. Not too long ago, I was invited to a special ceremony honouring our Olympic athletes who represented us in the winter games. I was very honoured to go. It was sponsored by the Secretary of State. It was right here on Parliament Hill.
In the room there was a nice big backdrop. There was a large Canadian flag on the mast, the proper Canadian flag, red with the maple leaf. Plastered in that backdrop of blue were blue Canadian flags. I even go a step further to mention the uniforms that our athletes wore in some of the Olympic games. They were representing Canada and the colours of our flag were not the number one predominant focal point of those uniforms.
I say to you, Mr. Speaker, and other colleagues that the Canadian flag is recognized throughout the world. I would hope that at least the Canadian government would help to preserve the true colours of that Canadian flag.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to rise to speak on the motions which are now put before the House by the hon. member for Don Valley East.
I want to commend the hon. member for Don Valley East for giving the House a long overdue opportunity to debate these important issues surrounding the pensions of members of Parliament. At the same time, I want to

point out that it was my own leader, the leader of the federal New Democratic Party, the member for Yukon, who first drew to the attention of Canadians in a very powerful speech on February 24 of this year the profound inequities which many Canadians believe exist in this pension plan.
I want to make it clear that in speaking today on these motions I am speaking personally. I am not speaking on behalf of my caucus colleagues, I am not speaking on behalf of my party. I am speaking personally and I am speaking as the member of Parliament for Burnaby- Kingsway.
I know my colleague for Victoria has strong feelings on this issue as well and he may very well be participating in the debate. Because of the intensity around this issue, it is a debate which transcends political considerations. I did want to make that very clear.
Certainly many of my constituents in Burnaby-Kingsway have raised concerns about the equity and the fairness of the members of Parliament's pension plan. As the member for Yukon, the leader of the New Democratic Party stated during her speech in February, we are accountable for the public trust. We are accountable to those who elected us to make sure that what we support is fair, not less, and that each and every one of us can stand before the electorate of Canada and say that we have put in place a fair system.
That is the benchmark which surely must guide us as we examine this pension system. As I look at the pension system today and as I looked at the pension system when I was first elected to this House some 13 years ago, it is clear to me that there are inequities in the system and that certainly this House should direct an independent review of those inequities.
On December 5, 1991 I tabled in this House the following motion: "That in the opinion of this House the government should consider the advisability of establishing a non-partisan, independent commission to review all salaries, pensions and benefits of members of Parliament and particularly to identify inequities in the pension plan by holding public hearings and examining other jurisdictions within and outside Canada, and such commission to report within six months of its establishment.
Government Orders
I believed then and I believe now that kind of completely independent review of our pension plan is long overdue. The leader of the New Democratic Party, the member for Yukon, has said in her speech in February that it is long overdue that we raise the question of pensions of members of this House, pensions that at this time mean that after six years of service members of this House receive a pension regardless of age or whether they move on to employment elsewhere in the federal government.
That refers to the so-called double-dipping provisions and these are the two fundamental elements of the amendments which are proposed by the member for Don Valley East.
I welcome the opportunity provided by the motions of the hon. member for Don Valley East for a comprehensive and independent review of the pensions and benefits of members of this House.
I also want to take this opportunity to signal the fact that as a result of the leadership of the hon. member for Yukon, the President of the Treasury Board within the last 24 hours has signalled that at last he is prepared to put together an independent and ad hoc review of the pension scheme. It was in response to yet another letter from the hon. member for Yukon, a letter in which the leader of the New Democratic Party called upon the President of the Treasury Board to establish an independent committee, an arm's length committee, that would be able to examine and make recommendations on all aspects of MPs' pension plans and to report back to Parliament within six months of being struck.
In response to that letter, the President of the Treasury Board replied as follows: "At this time, I am developing final proposals on the terms of reference for and composition of the ad hoc group which will undertake this review.
There is no question in my mind that all aspects of the Members of Parliament Retiring Allowances Act must be examined and that the study group should be made up of individuals with expertise and public credibility in the area of pensions and compensations".
I would certainly hope that it would be a completely independent review body, separate and at arm's length from members of Parliament and from retired members of Parliament.

June 12, 1992

This does give us an opportunity to review these issues. Certainly the member's motions are not likely to be adopted by the House today. As I understand it, there is some considerable resistance to the amendments. Again, this does give us an opportunity to help spur that long overdue review of the area of MPs' pensions and benefits.
Whether that review will result in proposals for change identical to those made by the hon. member for Don Valley East, whether there will be other proposals, a combination of service and age, whether there will be other proposals with respect to double-dipping, the independent commission will have an opportunity to review.
Again and in conclusion, I want to signal the leadership of the hon. member for Yukon, the leader of the New Democratic Party, in flagging this issue. I know it was a rather sensitive subject because I was in the House the day that she spoke. I remember the hon. member for Glengariy-Prescott-Russell for the Liberal Party and members of the Conservative Party getting up and braying that this was sacred territory; do not touch members of Parliament's pensions, for God's sake.
It was that unholy alliance that coalesces every so often in this country too often for many of us between the Liberal Party and the Conservative Party.
I want to take this opportunity to commend the hon. member for Don Valley East for once again speaking out independently and in particular for underlining and re-enforcing the leadership and the courage of the hon. member for Yukon on this important issue of public concern.

Mr. Speaker, I will not debate the point but for the record, those who are watching the proceedings should be aware of the position in committee of the members of that committee.
From day one, the members of that committee have asked for an independent review and that includes the members of the government. It was the government that has gone along and has agreed to that independent review. I do not see where the NDP leader should be the great one who decided that thanks to her we now have an independent review. I do not see why she should get all this credit.
It has been an agreed direction from day one. The members of the Liberal Party in committee asked for it and agreed with it. The member of the NDP who was there asked for it. Even the parliamentary secretary at one of the committee meetings put forth the point of view that he would support an independent review and would take that message to the minister.
Obviously the minister did listen to the hon. parliamentary secretary. It is not necessarily one member who should get the credit. If I recall well enough, when the hon. member for Yukon spoke here, the hon. member changed her position not too long after, publicly, a couple of days later. She did not seem to have the same position all of a sudden. I would not be too quick in saying the hon. member should deserve all the credit on this one.

Mr. Speaker, on a point of order. Certainly if there is any uncertainty I would be very pleased to seek the consent of the House to table the exchange of correspondence between the leader of the New Democratic Party and the President of the Treasury Board. I would seek that consent.

Mr. Speaker, as the New Democratic Party critic who attended the committee meetings and sat before the minister when he came before the committee, that was the argument the New Democratic Party had put forward. Our leader made it very clear in the House as I remember and the record in Hansard will verify who took the leadership in this.
I want to speak to the amendment because I think I have a great deal of respect for the member for Don Valley East and I admire his courage in bringing this forward. I have a problem with his amendment and the reason I have a problem with it is that I am a former mayor of a city. I remember when we used to have to vote ourself an increase in the city and I found that appalling.
I find it appalling today that we should be putting amendments forward on our own pension schemes. I like the process of having some actuaries out there and look at the problems that members of Parliament have
June 12, 1992

because maybe we should not be dealing with those problems within a pension bill.
I came here in 1980 and in 1984 I was defeated. I stood up in this House and took on my company, CP Rail. I travelled across this country fighting against the Crow's Nest agreement. Mr. Speaker, I compliment the member who just spoke now. He gave some balance to what had been said previously and it is not easy. This is not an easy subject. I have tackled the critics of MPs' benefits and pensions probably more than anyone in this House, save the member perhaps from Mississauga South. I feel some-

what bruised by the process, but as they say, them's the breaks. I am not ashamed to be a member of Parliament. I think it is the greatest honour any Canadian can have. I started my working career on Parliament Hill as a busboy in the Parliamentary Restaurant on October 25, 1966. I looked in awe at members of Parliament, looking in awe at those people who had been chosen democratically by fellow citizens to represent them in this the highest court in the land.

money to continue fighting more of this great stuff he is fighting now.
