But let us not take off to please the National Citizens Coalition and adopt an amendment or two or three amendments just because we are afraid of the Reform Party or David Somerville or somebody else. Let us have a bit more backbone around this place for once. Let us do that independent study. I know right now what it is going to say. I can tell you that most members of Parliament work hard-not just me, not just the member for Ottawa Vanier, although he works very hard, too, but members across the way, on all sides of the House. We all work hard around here and it is time that we took pride ourselves in the greatest honour that was given to us by our constituents who sent us here to start with.

Mr. Speaker, I strongly support the proposal for an independent inquiry into MPs' pensions, as proposed by the Leader of the New Democratic Party. It is an excellent initiative she has taken and it is long overdue.
The motion before this House from the member for Don Valley East I am afraid does not do the job because it is too rigid. I would think that the proposal he has put should go to this inquiry and be considered along with it. It does not have the necessary flexibility to cover some particular situations. Someone may be asked to do a short-term job. Someone may have a pension after six years which is minimal and which the member is entirely entitled to. That member ought to be free to accept some additional income.
The problem that the member's motion deals with and which I think is the public's concern is the person at full pension who is offered some full-time job in the public sector. That issue does need to be dealt with.
There are terrible inequities in this country in the whole pension field. Probably none is worse than the pensions of the captains of industry in this country who are paid grotesque pensions. We cannot do anything about those issues today in this bill. We can today deal with the issue of pensions of members of Parliament. It is incumbent upon us as members of Parliament to be prepared to have our pensions undergo the scrutiny of an independent inquiry.
We, too, may have to make sacrifices in this particular time of economic restraint in our country. Therefore, I welcome the initiative of the Leader of the New Democratic Party and I fully support the inquiry that she has proposed and has persuaded the government to implement.

I think it is very important in this present economic time that we who are members of Parliament think not just of the work which we do as MPs, think not just of the sacrifices which many members of Parliament make in terms of giving up income to be MPs. I think it is more important and more sensible in looking at this question from a broad economic perspective across the country to ask where we are at in Canada today.
In my constituency just today, workers at one of our large parts plants received notices that that plant is going to be shut down. Close to 200 workers will lose their jobs. Most of those workers will have been proud of their jobs. They will have been proud of their contribution that they have made to the company for which they worked. They are going to be proud of the community of which they are part. Many of them will have worked in that company for 15, 20, or 25 years. Yet when they leave that company by September after that amount of work, they will not
June 12, 1992

receive a pension. They will have worked more than six years but they will not receive a pension.
For those people let me suggest it will be considerably more difficult than for virtually anybody in this House of Commons to be able to find a job. Those who are 50, 51 or 52 or even if they are a little younger will not find it easy at all with unemployment at 11.2 per cent in this country to go out and find employment.
They will face exactly what each of us will face if we are defeated in the next election with one major difference. For somebody who has been here for six years, seven years, for eight years as in my case or for longer as in the case of other members, they will go out to seek employment. They will find it difficult perhaps but frankly, their experience here will help them rather than hurt them in virtually every case.
They will carry with them right from the day they lose their position in this House of Commons a pension of $20,000, $30,000 or $40,000.1 have had to talk with union presidents from plants that have faced this kind of shutdown. They said to me: "Steven, I have 23 years in at the plant where I happen to work and I am not going to have a pension. I do not know what I am going to do. I fought the company hard as chairperson of the union or as president of the union and it is not going to be easy for me in this community to find a new job because I am recognized as a union activist".
I say to members of this House of Commons, as I have said within my own caucus, that we have to recognize that the world is not an easy to place for many Canadians. It is not an easy place for the 460,000 Canadians who have lost manufacturing jobs in the last three and a half years.
It is not an easy place for people who find the unemployment insurance system much tougher now as a result of measures passed by a majority of members of Parliament in this House of Commons. I say that the motions which have been brought forward today by the member for Don Valley East are motions which personally I support and which I have supported before the time that I was elected as a member of Parliament.
Government Orders
One of the issues in the first campaign that I ran in in 1984 involved the fact that the member whom I was running to replace, the former member for Essex- Windsor, the former Minister of Agriculture, was being appointed to a government position in Rome. Yet he would receive a full pension from this House of Commons. I said at the time and I say now that it is not right. We need a good pension system for members of Parliament. There is no question about that.
As finance critic for our party, I also want to say that this country is hurting. There needs to be examples set. These examples should be set by this House of Commons by putting into effect positions such as those that have been put forward by the member for Don Valley East.
The member for Don Valley East would probably be the first to agree that it is not right that this House of Commons should have control over our pensions or over our other benefits. I do not think this House of Commons should be responsible for setting our salaries. I do not think it should be responsible for setting the allowances which we receive for keeping a residence in our constituencies and so forth.
An independent commission should be established to set these things out, just as is done with the setting of boundaries for constituencies in this country. We learned long ago that if we left the setting of boundaries to members of Parliament that there would be inevitably self-interested motives that would creep in to the setting of those boundaries. We must learn the same thing with respect to the whole set of benefits which a member of Parliament receives for the work which he or she does in this place, in our constituencies and elsewhere throughout the country. That is what we have to establish.
This is an important debate. It is an important set of motions which the member for Don Valley East has put forward. I hope they will be taken to an independent commission and we will reform the pension system of members of Parliament to make it fair and to make it in a context of difficult economic times for all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to add a few remarks to the debate.
I would like to quote from the report on the Members of Parliament Retiring Allowances Act for the fiscal year, 1989-90. What I would like to mention is that members do contribute to their pension plan. In the fiscal year 1989-90 they contributed $2,082 million and the government contributed the same amount.
The plan that is presently in force has a surplus in the bank of over $30 million. Naturally this brings in interest so that it is self-financing, I would say.
If we look at the number of pensions ex-members are getting, it is surprising to see for instance that about 60 former members are getting pensions in the order of $500 to $3,000 and there are only seven former members who get $50,000 plus. The average is probably around $15,000 to $16,000.
I would like to mention a friend of mine who was a member here for many years, about 20 years, and who was a cabinet minister in the Clark government. When he was defeated in 1980 his pension was $14,000. At the present time he is receiving $20,000 because his pension is indexed. I do not see how he could spend 20 years in government service, been a cabinet minister and receive a pension of $20,000.
If you look at the whole issue I feel it has been blown out of proportion. The plan is self-financing, it has a surplus and it has been very well run. I think the stories that we hear about members getting huge amounts of money are somewhat false. Members who have served in this House for some time deserve a pension. These members left their professional lives and businesses. Many come from long distances such as British Columbia and the Atlantic provinces and cannot run their businesses from Ottawa.
My feeling is that members are really not getting what the public perceives they are getting. The report further states that another 15 members are getting from $3,000 to $4,000. In total there are only 332 ex-members who are getting pensions and of that only seven receive $50,000 and 27 receiving $40,000 to $50,000. It then goes down to $500.
Therefore, I believe we should have a serious look at the pension proposals. We should not be defensive about what members of Parliament are getting. If you look for instance at what some provincial members are getting
you might be surprised. They get much higher pensions than we do. Some of the salaries in the provinces are double what members of Parliament get.
I do not think we should be defensive about our pensions. I tend to disagree with the member who just spoke. He talked about other institutions and doubledipping. If there is double-dipping I think it should be disallowed across the board because there are certain members who retire in other government institutions at age 50 with huge pensions and they are double-dipping as well. If we have double-dipping I think it should apply across the board.

He said: Mr. Speaker, this is a very important amendment. It deals with the fairness issue, something which I have been repeatedly saying today. I think that our amendments over-all addressed fairness.
Prior to the change in the family law legislation, many spouses received their pensions as support. Legislation stated that the pension was an asset but it was either implicitly recognized by the courts that the spouses had an entitlement to the pension or that it was unfair that they be deprived of an entitlement especially after long-term marriages.
I could quote, but I do not want to take too much time, letters from constituents, as well as comments and statements. I want to quote briefly from a constituent of mine, Joyce Struthers, who has been very active in representing the committee for spousal's and children's pension survival and related benefits. I think we owe Ms. Struthers a vote of thanks for her presentation and her fairness.
Many spouses were married for 20, 30, 40, 50 years. They shared all the contributions, supported all the employment, carried all the family responsibilities, bore the children, lost their own employment in many cases, lost their pension opportunities as an individual because they were married to a public servant and were keeping house and doing things that were required because the spouse was away from home, sometimes in a foreign country. They often represented Canada side by side with their spouse.
These people are asking for an amendment that would fine tune the legislation, making it appropriate that since many spouses have elected to take their entitlement to the pension as support rather than as an asset in order to be able to obtain enforcement through the Garnishment, Attachment and Pension Diversion Act, these persons would be allowed to apply for the benefits available under the new Pension Benefits Division Act.
To them and to the Liberals on this side, this is crucial because these women were advised to take the pension this way by their lawyers, by Treasury Board officials. Many judges have made similar orders because the

Garnishment, Attachment and Pension Diversion Act did not allow for a division of assets but only for support.
Those provisions under the Garnishment, Attachment and Pension Diversion Act are currently being challenged in the courts under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Again it is a question of justice. It is a question of equity. It is a question of fairness. All these people are proposing through us in this amendment is that this House be sensitive to a difficult situation. I could speak at length on this subject matter but I will not because I think the point has been made. We must show some considerate attention to these particular cases and adopt a motion that indeed would correct it.

We are saying with this amendment that it is incumbent upon the member who has the pension to notify the spouse so that she is aware of the divisions within that pension. It is a small amendment and it is one that the government should certainly accept.
During the debate in committee and during the debate in the House on these amendments, on simple amendments such as this one, not one member of the government is getting up and telling us why he or she would not consider this amendment. I think that is disrespectful to the employees of the Public Service, disrespectful to members of the RCMP and disrespectful to military groups.

Mr. Speaker, I am speaking to Motions Nos. 73B and 78B which I moved and which were seconded by my friend and colleague from Restigouche-Chaleur.
The purpose of these amendments is directed primarily at the Canadian forces, diplomatic services and other federal employees who may be posted in different locations across the land or outside the country.
Some of these employees have been known to live apart from their legal spouses and take on common law spouses without the knowledge of the legal spouses. This section, unamended, would not be fair to a spouse who carried on her duties raising the family and believing herself to be in a stable family relationship, and meanwhile her spouse had struck or arranged a common law association unknown to the legal spouse. In my view the legal spouse in this situation is short-changed. She is short-changed of benefits without even knowing what her legal or economic position is.
The amendment I am proposing is simply trying to require that the legal spouse be informed, and I underline that, that the couple is living separate and apart. It sounds to me like a reasonable, sensible amendment.
On that question there has been a long debate as to why the government would not come to grips with this situation, which in many cases is a tragedy. It is a tragic situation because innocent people are being hurt. We all know this could be avoided by amending the law, by making it possible to avoid serious injustice, by adopting a motion which would correct this exploitation and by simply dropping one optional basis, that is the provision for payout on marriage breakdown, and providing instead authority for making the former spouse of the public servant a member of the pension plan. It does not seem to me to be a very complicated proposal.
I take it that the spouse at home is entitled to half, at least, of the contribution that her spouse and herself make to a pension plan. That is fair. That is an entitlement which I understand to be a just analysis of the situation.
This does not belong to one spouse. It belongs to both of them. These are earnings that are put away, saved for later use. That is a pension plan. That is why we contribute to pension plans. It is earnings today that are saved for future use.
Instead of having some injustice in a situation of marriage breakdown because the spouse receiving or contributing directly to the pension plan is having another relationship, common law or otherwise, all we are saying is that there should be an additional clause that says the spouse who is legally entitled to it should receive half those contributions and be entitled to some pension plan.
In my riding many families are affected. I know families in the Canadian forces at Rockcliffe who were subjected to this kind of situation. It is not an easy thing to settle.
I dare say that the government's answer to our proposal was: "We do not want to increase the numbers of recipients or the number of pensioners". It does not sound to me like a very positive answer or a very acceptable one in that sense.
Logic would simply dictate that this amendment is not a far-reaching or very difficult one to understand. It would be one of fairness and it would be one of justice. I hope my colleagues will see their way to supporting this amendment.

Mr. Speaker, we have now moved into a section of the bill which in effect is a whole new bill to be entitled the Pension Benefits Division Act, schedule II of the bill before the House.
The bill rights a very long injustice mostly to women who are the ex-spouses of public servants, including the military, the RCMP and so forth. Under federal pension plans ex-spouses have been denied what the courts and the provincial level have agreed they should have, that is a clear recognition that through their marriage they have contributed equally to the pension plan earned by their spouses. That has already been recognized in the Canada Pension Plan. It has been recognized at the provincial level. It has been recognized by the courts, and now finally it is being recognized by Parliament. It is a change which we on all sides of the House support.
June 12, 1992

The member for New Westminster-Burnaby has been one of the leading spokespeople on this issue and has worked with women's groups across the country in bringing this issue to the attention of Parliament.
In my own riding there are courageous women who have come forward with petitions and requests. Some of the most poignant letters I have read have dealt with the plight they have been put in by this Parliament's failure to move earlier on this issue. They have been deprived of rights they should have. It is in this context therefore that I want to speak about the particular amendments before the House.
The member for Kootenay East moved a number of amendments in committee and made some great strides forward. He won an amendment for disclosure requiring that the non-plan member spouses will now have equal access to their spouses' pension information. In the absence of a court order specifying the period of cohabitation, the minister can and must use provincial family law guidelines in determining the period. Finally, there have been improvements in the valuation of the pension rights.
There are still a number of key points missing from the bill and issues which the committee heard eloquent pleas about. The committee for spousal and children pension survival and related benefits led by Joyce Struthers and others across Canada have made a veiy persuasive case for these issues.
I would just like to review them. We have already heard about some. The member for Kootenay East referred to Motion No. 73, which simply says that for calculating the period of contribution, the spouse at least ought to be given notice of the separation. That is a simple matter of justice.
Motion No. 75 which is included in this group would deal with the problem that an appeal of a court order could unfairly defer the rights to the asset which this Parliament concedes is earned by the ex-spouse.
Motions Nos. 76 and 76A in my name deal with the issue of retroactivity. The bill already provides a certain limited transitional provision. If the ex-spouse is lucky enough to have had this included in the court order or separation agreement entered into before this act comes into force, she or he may be all right.
If the court order or separation agreement does not cover the division of pension benefits, which may well be the case because of course up until this act comes into force it is not the law, then that person may be out of luck. The ex-spouse can try to go back to court, try to go
Government Orders
back to the ex-spouse and negotiate a new agreement, but if that cannot be done, and there may be statute limitations and other reasons why that is not possible, then the ex-spouse is out of luck.
What the amendment I have moved proposes is simple and I ask the House to support it. Give the minister the authority to change the court order or pension plan and approve a division of pension benefits in appropriate cases.
I had extensive discussions with officials of Treasury Board and the associate Minister of National Defence, who is also the Minister responsible for the Status of Woman. She gave strong support not only to the bill itself, but to the thrust of the amendment I was proposing.
Somewhere deep in the bowels of Treasury Board they could not agree to this simple amendment because they are afraid their minister might have to make a difficult decision. So what did the government members of the committee do? They simply said we will only do what Treasury Board says. What is the government doing today? Silence. Silence in the face of the call for justice for women in this country who have inadvertently been deprived of a possible benefit. I think it is unconscionable for the members of the government to sit silent through this.
There are other amendments which are covered in this package. Frequently a court order or a separation agreement may recognize the spouse is entitled to more than 50 per cent because there are trade-offs, but this bill prevents the minister from recognizing that.
It is an arbitrary limit which has no basis of justice. I am amazed that the members of the government would sit silent and allow this to not be supported in this House.
We finally come to two or three other amendments. I do not know how much time I have. Two minutes. Well, in two minutes I can try to make a further pitch for those who have a case here to which the government is deaf.

Mr. Speaker, as you know I had moved some motions myself to amend this portion of the legislation, which deals with credit splitting for spouses and ex-spouses of pensioners under this legislation.
I would like to commend the hon. members who have spoken and moved motions on this portion of the legislation. They include the hon. member for Kootenay East, the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier and the hon. member for Victoria.
I suspect almost everyone in this House has constituents who have a problem, and who have had a problem which they hope will be solved by this legislation. I have many, but I would just like to put on the record the
concerns of one of those constituents who I have been discussing this matter with for many years.
Mrs. Joyce Bisset, one of my constituents who lives in Vicora Linkway, wrote me on October 31, 1991 to say: "I have written you several times in the past, specifically in 1987 and 1988, in regard to the unfairness of federal legislation, which discriminates against former spouses of military and public servants. I wrote to you about both pension credit splitting and survivor benefits earned during the years of marriage".
"Just prior to the last election, I invited you into my home at which time we discussed these issues. I did provide you with copies of my correspondence for you to read. You did tell me that if federal legislation was not forthcoming following your letters of referral to the correct ministers in charge that you would introduce a private members' bill yourself to have the legislation changed".
"I am sure that you can understand my disappointment in not receiving anything positive in regard to these pressing issues. I have enclosed a petition which has been signed by my doctor because of the stress-related illness that I have suffered including life-threatening major surgery in 1990 and also by strong supporters of this issue, some of whom find it to be unbelievable that in this day and age such discrimination exists".
That petition read:
That many women in Canada are living in poverty after years of home making, which allowed their husbands to pursue careers without the burden of of child rearing and housework.
That many of these women are disentitled by divorce to an equal share of their husband's federal pension credits accumulated during their marriage, and
That the government has stated in the past that it is in favour of mandatory, automatic pension credit splitting.
In fact, the Canada Pension Plan has had that for some time.
Therefore, your petitioners request that Parliament consider amending all federal superannuation acts in which inequity exists to allow for the retroactive pension credit splitting for all divorced spouses so that they may receive one-half of the federal pension credits accumulated by both spouses during the years of their marriage.
June 12, 1992

That is not an uncommon kind of situation. There are lots and lots of homemaker spouses who are in that situation and have been in that situation. I know that myself from my own family's circumstances.
My uncle was a military officer until his retirement, my aunt worked along with him. They were a team. It seems incredible to me that somebody in Mrs. Bisset's case could not share on a credit splitting basis the pension of her husband in a situation like that where suddenly as was the case with Mrs. Bisset almost to the day that her husband retired from the military he left and is living with another woman.
As a result of that, Mrs. Bisset did not have any access whatsoever to the credits of her husband's pension. This bill helps to correct some of those inequities but as hon. members have said already there are many more inequities that have not been corrected as yet by this bill.
In the motions that I have put before the House, Motion No. 74 deals with the whole situation of what happens when there is a separation. Do you go on for a period of weeks, months, years perhaps before suddenly the credit splitting starts, or the payments to the one spouse end pending some sort of decision.
I have provided in Motion No. 74 that there will be a freeze on those payments upon notice from the spouse who is a party to this separation until there is a decision made.
I have also provided in Motions Nos. 77 and 78 that there is a right for the minister to determine that the deserted, separated or divorced spouse in those cases should be entitled to receive more than 50 per cent of the pension if she has contributed that proportionate amount over the time, in the judgment of the minister.
I would hope that the members of this House would see fit to adopt all of the motions that have been put on this issue which raise very longstanding concerns on matters of complete inequity and it is long overdue that this Parliament correct these inequities. After all, we have corrected them in the Canada Pension Plan. There is no reason why we should not be correcting them in this legislation also.

colleague from Ottawa West as well was very active in raising this issue.
Just very briefly I want to say to the House that Motion No. 78B is meant to address the following problem. Bill C-55 currently says that the amount of the pension to be transferred is 50 per cent or less even if the court order takes the entire pension into account in the division of assets, and the words "more than 50 per cent" to one spouse.
If this was a pension in the private sector regulated by any statute, federal or provincial, none of us would interfere with that. A court order would be respected. However, when we are dealing with pensions for public servants it seems that we have decided that we can inject something into the bill whereby we will supersede the order made by a judge of the court, having taken a number of things into consideration in the disposition of assets. The proposed amendment would enable the federal government to award the amount of the pension stated in the court order, whatever the court order, whether it is 50 per cent, more than 50 per cent or whether it is less. In fact, the amendment would bring this legislation in line with the Pension Benefits Standards Act which is the act which we use to impose those kinds of rules on everyone else. The amendment proposed by my colleague would inject that element of fairness that has been raised by other colleagues earlier today. I just wanted to take a moment of the House and so indicate.

Motion No. 75D.
That Bill C-55 be amended in Schedule II by striking out lines 16 to 22 at page 154 and substituting the following therefor:
"those grounds are based."
He said: Mr. Speaker, the purpose of this amendment is to remove two paragraphs of the proposed Pension Benefits Division Act which state that the minister shall refuse to approve the division of pension benefits if, and it reads:
(d)	That periods subject to division cannot be determined under subsection 8(2) or 8(3) or
(e)	The minister is satisfied, based on evidence submitted to the minister that it would not be just to approve this division.
Mr. Speaker, we want those two paragraphs deleted.
In the case of (d), subsections (2) and (3) of the same act give ample guidelines as to how to determine a period subject to division and gives the minister the power to declare a period as the period of co-habitation even in the absence of court order or spousal agreement specifying such a period. Spouses should not be refused the part of the pension they earned because the minister has not exercised his power to declare a period of co-habitation.
Concerning paragraph (e), which we also want deleted, the proposed Pension Benefits Division Act states that pension credits cannot be divided in the absence of a court order or agreement. Paragraph (e) gives the minister the power to ignore a provincial court order or agreement between spouses as to the division of benefits for unnamed reasons. This is probably unconstitutional, as marital property is under provincial jurisdiction and provincial law is paramount in this area.

June 12, 1992
Government Orders
Other paragraphs are in place to prevent division if a court order is found to be invalid, the application for splitting is withdrawn or an appeal is underway.
Paragraph (e) may allow the minister to make decisions based on moral or other grounds, superseding valid court orders. This is unacceptable.

Mr. Speaker, in conclusion, the present law does not provide for sharing pension rights. This new bill, C-55, would allow sharing pension benefits at source. Of course, we are pleased with that and support some of those recommendations. The spouse's agreement or a court order would be required, if we take the bill literally; up to 50 per cent of the entitlement would be transferred to a retirement savings plan for the spouse and the participant's benefits in the plan would be adjusted accordingly.
All that proposed amendment 75D does is to give clear, specific directions, because we do not want grey areas. We want the minister to meet his responsibilities, but we also want all public servants and everyone entitled to a pension to know clearly that there are difficult situations where the same rules as apply to the Canada Pension Plan will apply to the Public Service Superannuation Act. The CPP provides for automatic sharing of pension benefits at source and the 1983 report of the parliamentary task force on pension reform recommended that this measure also apply to Public Service pensions, as we recall.
The purpose of my motion 75D is simply to update the bill and make it apply not only like all other bills but like all other systems.

He said: Mr. Speaker, I will be very brief. I do not want to take too much time of the House.
The purpose of this amendment is to allow for pension advisory committees to have representation from organizations representing spouses or former spouses of pension plan members.
It is a proposal that is fair, that would not cost any money. It would give us a chance to hear from those who sometimes are affected by these dispositions of the law and who clearly have a financial interest in the formulation of regulations that apply to these laws.
This amendment is strictly an attempt to ensure that these groups be heard, that they be consulted, and it is an amendment that wants to open up the process to those people involved and it simply asks that they be allowed to be heard at these advisory boards.
